NAVIGATION.question: 1: What are the different types of flight guidance?

options.text: A: Slaved and managed.
B: Automatic and manual.
C: Managed and selected.
D: Managed and manual

NAVIGATION.question: 2: One A/P can be engaged on the ground if the engines are not running.

options.text: A: This A/P will disengage when both engines are started.
B: This A/P will disengage when one engine is started.
C: This A/P will disengage when speed is sensed at > 10 kts.

NAVIGATION.question: 3: When the thrust levers are moved to the takeoff position, the FMGS updates its position at takeoff using:

options.text: A: IRS/DME/DME positioning.
B: IRS/ILS/DME positioning.
C: The navigation database and the takeoff runway entered into the MCDU by the pilot.
D: The VOR/DME currently tuned.

NAVIGATION.question: 4: The takeoff bias is:

options.text: A: Replaced when a bias is computed based on radio position.
B: Retained for the remainder of the flight.
C: Blended out over the next 30 minutes.

NAVIGATION.question: 5: With the DATA selector set to HDG, the time remaining until the completed IRS alignment is displayed on the control display. How long does it take normally?

options.text: A: Approximately 1 minute
B: Approximately 3 minutes
C: Approximately 7 minutes
D: Approximately 10 minutes

NAVIGATION.question: 6: How does the FMGS derive Vapp?

options.text: A: Vapp=Vls+5+(1/3 surface headwind component).
B: Vapp=Vls+10+1/3 surface headwind component.
C: Vapp=Vls+5+1/2 surface headwind component.
D: Vapp=Vls+10+1/2 surface headwind component.

NAVIGATION.question: 7: When flying at cruise altitude, the aircraft navigates using radio navaids only.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

NAVIGATION.question: 8: The IR alignment count down stops one minute prior to accomplishment and the ALIGN lights are flashing. Why does it happen?

options.text: A: It is an indication that there is a disagreement between the IRs and the alignment must be restarted.
B: It is an indication that the alignment is complete but must be acknowledged
C: It is an indication that alignment has stopped as the present position data has not been entered from the FMGS.

NAVIGATION.question: 9: What is managed climb speed below 10,000 feet?

options.text: A: Green dot.
B: 210 knots.
C: 250 knots.
D: Best rate of climb speed.

NAVIGATION.question: 10: The selected database date has expired. When must the active data base be changed?

options.text: A: Prior to entering the preflight data.
B: Anytime prior to takeoff.
C: The following calendar day.

NAVIGATION.question: 11: Which of the following navaids can be autotuned?

options.text: A: ILS and ADF (for NDB data base approaches).
B: VOR and DME.
C: Both are correct.

NAVIGATION.question: 12: Cost Index = 0 (zero) corresponds to:

options.text: A: Minimum fuel consumption (max range)
B: Minimum time.
C: Best ratio between the flight time cost and the fuel cost.
D: LRC (Long Range Cruise).

NAVIGATION.question: 13: While taxiing on the ground, the FMGS displays the position of the aircraft using:

options.text: A: IRS and DME/DME.
B: IRS only.
C: IRS and VOR/DME.
D: DME/DME and VOR/DME.

NAVIGATION.question: 14: With the autopilot engaged, either sidestick can be moved freely.

options.text: A: True.
B: False, moving either sidestick will cause the autopilot(s) to disengage
C: False, only the PNF’s sidestick will freely move.

NAVIGATION.question: 15: When the aircraft is in the Managed Guidance mode, it is:

options.text: A: Guided by the pilot selecting the specific flight modes and parameter target values on the FCU.
B: Responding to pilot inputs of speed, altitude, and heading selected on the FCU.
C: Following lateral, vertical and speed profiles as determined by the IRS’S.
D: Following lateral, vertical and speed profiles as determined by the FMGS.

NAVIGATION.question: 16: What is managed climb speed above 10,000 feet?

options.text: A: Green dot.
B: 250 knots.
C: 280 knots.
D: Econ climb speed.

NAVIGATION.question: 17: An amber box on the MCDU screen indicates:

options.text: A: An optional data entry.
B: A mandatory data entry.
C: A compulsory reporting point.
D: The waypoint indicated will be overflown

NAVIGATION.question: 18: Managed guidance is engaged by:

options.text: A: Pulling on the desired FCU selector knob.
B: Pushing on the desired FCU selector knob.
C: Rotating 90° the desired FCU selector knob.

NAVIGATION.question: 19: What speed will the FMGS use in an Expedite climb?

options.text: A: Green dot speed.
B: ECON climb speed.
C: 250 knots below 10,000 feet.
D: Amber dot speed.

NAVIGATION.question: 20: The weather radar image can be displayed on which modes of the ND?

options.text: A: Rose NAV or VOR.
B: Rose VOR or Rose ILS.
C: Rose NAV or ARC.
D: All modes except Plan.

NAVIGATION.question: 21: You have been cleared to intercept the localizer. You have pushed the LOC push button on the FCU. If all necessary data has been entered in the MCDU, can you now engage both autopilots?

options.text: A: No, the LOC must capture before both autopilots will engage.
B: Yes.
C: No, the APPR pushbutton must be pushed.

NAVIGATION.question: 22: During a turnaround, you notice that there is a residual ground speed on both NDs. How do you correct this?

options.text: A: As the engines have been shut down, it is necessary to carry out a full re-alignment.
B: There is no corrective action possible until the aircraft is completely electrically shut down.
C: It is possible to carry out a rapid alignment by turning off all 3 ADIRS momentarily.

NAVIGATION.question: 23: SRS will command:

options.text: A: V2 + 10 with both engines operating
B: V2 or current aircraft speed (whichever is higher) in the case of an engine failure.
C: Best rate of climb taking into account actual wind component.

NAVIGATION.question: 24: In flight, either the AP/FD pitch control, or autothrust may acquire and hold a target speed or Mach number, depending on the engaged modes. Speed control is “Managed” when the target comes from the SPD/MACH FCU window

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

NAVIGATION.question: 25: The FMGS data base contains:

options.text: A: Performance information, such as engine fuel flow, engine thrust, green dot data (L/D data), etc.
B: Navigation information, such as navaids, waypoints, airways, airports, runways, etc.
C: Both are correct.

NAVIGATION.question: 26: If one GPS receiver fails, the three ADIRUs automatically select the only operative GPS receiver.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

NAVIGATION.question: 27: FMGC 1 is not working. To enter data into the FMGC, which MCDU would you use?

options.text: A: MCDU 1 on the Captain’s side.
B: MCDU 2 on the First Officer’s side.
C: Either MCDU 1 or MCDU 2.

NAVIGATION.question: 28: The pilot interfaces with the FMGS using the:

options.text: A: FCU.
B: Thrust Levers.
C: MCDU.
D: All of the above.

NAVIGATION.question: 29: When is the SRS active?

options.text: A: During a Go Around (after the thrust levers are placed in the TOGA position) up to the acceleration altitude.
B: At T/O, when TOGA or FLX power is set, SRS is displayed on the FMA and provides guidance up to the acceleration altitude
C: Both are correct.

NAVIGATION.question: 30: The energy circle is a green arc, centered on the aircraft’s position and oriented towards the current track line. It is displayed on the NDs during descent, when HDG or TRK mode is selected.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

NAVIGATION.question: 31: Can the crew depress the RMP ON NAV pushbutton and use the RMP for navigation simultaneously with FMGC autotuning?

options.text: A: Yes, because the opposite FMGC will continue to autotune navaids.
B: No, RMP backup tuning supersedes the autotuning function of both FMGC’s.

NAVIGATION.question: 32: What do the white round lights on the FCU display mean?

options.text: A: Selected guidance has been engaged.
B: Automatic guidance has been engaged.
C: Managed guidance has been armed or engaged.

NAVIGATION.question: 33: The Captain’s FMA indicates - FD2 in column five, line two. What does this mean?

options.text: A: FMGC #1 has timed out and flight guidance is lost.
B: The First Officer has pushed the priority takeover pushbutton.
C: FMGC #1 has timed out and FMGC #2 is now providing flight guidance for both pilots
D: The Captains FD pushbutton. on the FCU has not been selected ON and FD2 has automatically crossed over.

NAVIGATION.question: 34: During descent, if you push the Expedite (EXPED) push button, what speed will the aircraft try to maintain?

options.text: A: Green dot.
B: 340 knots
C: 3,000 fpm vertical speed.
D: standard 3.0 degrees angle of descent.

NAVIGATION.question: 35: OPEN CLIMB (OP CLB) is a Managed mode.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

NAVIGATION.question: 36: If you have depressed the EXPED push button and want to cancel this function, how could this be accomplished?

options.text: A: Push the EXPED push button again.
B: Pull the altitude, vertical speed, or speed knob.
C: Retard the thrust levers to IDLE.
D: A red “WIND SHR” light; an aural “WINDSHEAR, WINDSHEAR, WINDSHEAR”

NAVIGATION.question: 37: The LOC mode disengages when:

options.text: A: Another lateral mode is engaged.
B: The pilot presses the LOC pushbutton again (engaging the HDG/TRK mode on the current HDG/TRK).
C: Both are correct.

NAVIGATION.question: 38: Will the aircraft capture and navigate via the ILS signals if the ILS push button on the FCU is not pushed?

options.text: A: Yes
B: No.

NAVIGATION.question: 39: The three Display Management Computers (DMCS) acquire and process all input from airplane sensors and computers to generate the display images.

options.text: A: True
B: False

NAVIGATION.question: 40: The aircraft has _______ Air Data Inertial Reference Units (ADIRU’s).
41: GPWS aural and visual warnings cannot be inhibited.

options.text: A: True
B: False

NAVIGATION.question: 42: Selection of the correct takeoff runway on the FMGC prior to each flight is necessary because:

options.text: A: The FADEC needs it to know how much to reduce the thrust for takeoff.
B: Selection of the correct runway insures proper pressurization.
C: Selection of the correct runway permits the FMGC to update its position at takeoff.

NAVIGATION.question: 43: The two basic modes of flight guidance are:

options.text: A: Slaved and coupled.
B: Managed and selected.
C: Manual and coupled.

NAVIGATION.question: 44: Both autopilots can be engaged and active in any phase of flight.

options.text: A: True
B: False

NAVIGATION.question: 45: All navaids are normally autotuned by:

options.text: A: The FMGC
B: MCDU
C: ADIRU

NAVIGATION.question: 46: VOR data can be displayed on:

options.text: A: Both NDs
B: The DDRMI
C: First two statements are correct

NAVIGATION.question: 47: What is the preferred method of radio position updating for the FMGS?

options.text: A: VOR/DME
B: ILS/DME
C: DME/DME

NAVIGATION.question: 48: The windshear function of the FAC’s is independent of the flight director on/off switch.

options.text: A: True
B: False

NAVIGATION.question: 49: All PFD displays except attitude; speed; heading; altitude; and vertical speed are removed when pitch attitude exceeds 25 degrees nose up or 13 degrees nose down.

options.text: A: True
B: False

NAVIGATION.question: 50: Sidestick position and max. sidestick deflection are displayed on the ground on the PFD:

options.text: A: Continuously after aircraft power is applied.
B: After the first engine start.
C: On takeoff roll when power is applied.

NAVIGATION.question: 51: The airspeed indication on the PFD starts at:

options.text: A: 100 kts.
B: 80 kts
C: 50 kts.
D: 30 kts

NAVIGATION.question: 52: The speed trend arrow on the PFD airspeed scale indicates the speed value that will be attained in _____ seconds if the acceleration remains constant.
53: Radio Height is displayed on the PFD:

options.text: A: Below 2500 feet.
B: When the LOC or APPR p/b is pressed.
C: When a Decision Height is selected.

NAVIGATION.question: 54: The Armed Vertical Modes are displayed on the Flight Mode Annunciator on the second line in:

options.text: A: Blue or magenta.
B: Blue or green.
C: White

NAVIGATION.question: 55: ILS 1 information is displayed on ______ when operating in the rose ILS mode:

options.text: A: PFD 2 & ND 1
B: PFD 1 & ND 1
C: PFD 1 & ND 2

NAVIGATION.question: 56: When a double entry is needed on the MCDU (e.g. wind direction/speed: 270/110) the separating slash must be used. The trailing entry of a pair must be preceded by a slash if it is entered alone.

options.text: A: True
B: False

NAVIGATION.question: 57: The Engaged Vertical Modes are displayed on the Flight Mode Annunciator on the first line in:

options.text: A: Green or Blue
B: Green or Magenta
C: Blue

NAVIGATION.question: 58: The ON BAT light on the ADIRS CDU illuminates:

options.text: A: Only when all IRU’s are on battery power.
B: When an IRU fault is detected.
C: When one or more ADIRU’s; are supplied by airplane battery only.

NAVIGATION.question: 59: In the event of failure of the AIR DATA function of ADIRU 1 or 2; the affected displays can be manually selected over to ADR 3 by the:

options.text: A: ECAM/ND transfer selector.
B: AIR DATA selector.
C: ATT HDG selector.

NAVIGATION.question: 60: Box prompts on the MCDU indicate data:

options.text: A: Entry is optional for FMGS operation.
B: Entry is required for minimum FMGS operation.
C: will be filled in by the FMGS.

NAVIGATION.question: 61: An FMGS message which requires immediate attention is displayed in:

options.text: A: Red
B: Amber
C: Magenta

NAVIGATION.question: 62: If the FLEX TEMP is not entered on the Takeoff Page of the MCDU:

options.text: A: A FLX takeoff is still available; set power with the thrust levers.
B: The FMGS will enter it for you based on TAT.
C: A FLX takeoff is not available.

NAVIGATION.question: 63: Zero Fuel Weight is entered on:

options.text: A: Init B page.
B: Prog page.
C: Perf page.

NAVIGATION.question: 64: If the SPD/MACH knob on the FCU is not pulled within a predetermined time to engage selected speed:

options.text: A: The selection can be made at any time.
B: The selection is lost and dashes are re-displayed.
C: The selection is lost and the display goes blank.

NAVIGATION.question: 65: When the altitude knob on the FCU is pulled:

options.text: A: The altitude is armed.
B: The current altitude is canceled.
C: OPEN CLIMB or DESCENT engages.

NAVIGATION.question: 66: The Standby Attitude indication will remain available for ______ minutes after total electrical failure.

FUEL.question: 1: Refueling is possible if the aircraft batteries are the only source of power.

options.text: A: True
B: False

FUEL.question: 2: With the center tank pump mode SEL switch in AUTO; the center tank pumps:

options.text: A: Run for two minutes after both engines are running.
B: Will not restart untill slats are retracted in flight.
C: Continue to run until five minutes after the center tank is empty.
D: All the above.

FUEL.question: 3: Fuel transfer from the outer compartment to the inner compartment of the wing tanks occurs when the inner compartment quantity decreases to:

options.text: A: 250 kilograms
B: 450 kilograms
C: 750 kilograms
D: 5000 kilograms

FUEL.question: 4: What indication will you see on the overhead fuel panel if the center tank has more than 250 kilograms of fuel and the left or right wing tank have less than 5,000 kilograms.

options.text: A: Auto feed fault.
B: Fuel imbalance.
C: Mode select fault.
D: Fuel - Auto feed fault.

FUEL.question: 5: The Fuel Used indication on ECAM is reset:

options.text: A: Manually by the pilot.
B: Automatically at engine start on the ground.
C: Automatically at electric power up of the aircraft.

FUEL.question: 6: The fuel quantity indication on ECAM for the outer cell is boxed amber if:

options.text: A: One transfer valve fails to open.
B: Outer cell fuel temperature is high.
C: Both transfer valves fail to open when inner cell is at low level.

FUEL.question: 7: An amber line appears across the last two digits of the ECAM FOB indication when:

options.text: A: Fuel quantity is unreliable.
B: The center tank pumps are switched off.
C: The center tank pumps have failed.

FUEL.question: 8: The fuel crossfeed valve is controlled by 2 motors.

options.text: A: True
B: False

FUEL.question: 9: Which of the following would cause the fault light to illuminate on the MODE SEL push button?

options.text: A: Fuel is being burned out of sequence.
B: Crossfeed push button is ON.
C: Center tank pumps do not stop after slat extension.
D: Center tank pumps do not stop 5 min after center tank low level reached.

FUEL.question: 10: The message CTR TK FEEDG appears in the MEMO. What does this mean?

options.text: A: The center tank fuel mode selector is OFF.
B: The center tank pumps are OFF.
C: At least one center tank pump is energized.
D: A reminder to switch the center tank pumps OFF.

FUEL.question: 11: From which tanks will fuel gravity feed?

options.text: A: Outer cell of the wing tanks, inner cell of the wing tanks, and/or center tank.
B: Inner cell of the wing tanks, and center tank.
C: Outer cell of the wing tanks, and inner cell of the wing tanks.
D: The center tank only.

FUEL.question: 12: Center tank pumps do not stop 5 min after center tank low level reached.

options.text: A: Yes, only on the refueling panel.
B: It is not possible to determine their position
C: Only on the ECAM Fuel page.

FUEL.question: 13: During normal operations when should the fuel transfer valves open?

options.text: A: When a low level is sensed in the center tank.
B: When a low level is sensed in either outer wing cell.
C: When low level is sensed in either inner wing cell.

FUEL.question: 14: What does an amber line across the last two digits of the fuel quantity mean?

options.text: A: The fuel quantity indication is inaccurate.
B: The fuel quality is not good and should be checked.
C: A disagreement between fuel measured and fuel entered on the MCDU has been detected.
D: Not all the fuel aboard is useable.

FUEL.question: 15: The APU fuel system:

options.text: A: Uses its own dedicated DC powered fuel pump.
B: Obtains fuel from either center tank pump.
C: Obtains fuel from the left fuel manifold via the left side fuel pumps or if needed, the APU fuel pump.
D: Obtains fuel from the left fuel manifold via the right side fuel pumps.

FUEL.question: 16: With fuel in the center tank, the CTR TK MODE SEL push button selected to AUTO and the CTR TK PUMP push buttons ON (lights out), the center tank pumps:

options.text: A: Will operate for a short period after the first engine MASTER switch is selected ON and while slats are retracted.
B: They will continue to run until the center tank is empty or slats are extended.
C: Both are correct.

FUEL.question: 17: The AC powered auxiliary fuel boost pump for the APU operates whenever the APU is operating and no other pump is on. it has an alternate power source on the AC Static Inverter bus for battery-only starts.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

FUEL.question: 18: After engine start, center tank fuel pumps run for ______ minutes regardless of slat position.

options.text: A: 1 minute.
B: 2 minutes.
C: 3 minutes.
D: 5 minutes.

FUEL.question: 19: The message OUTER TK FUEL XFRD appears in the MEMO. What does this mean?

options.text: A: It is a reminder to show that a transfer valve is open.
B: Fuel is transferring from the center tank to the inner tank.
C: It is a reminder to open the outer tank transfer valve.
D: Fuel is transferring from the inner tank to the outer tank.

FUEL.question: 20: The wing fuel transfer valves are:

options.text: A: Manually controlled and open when the MODE SEL push button is selected to MAN.
B: Are electrically held closed.
C: Open automatically at the start of refueling.
D: Automatically close if a low level is sensed in either main wing tank, they automatically close at the next fueling.

FUEL.question: 21: Why do the center tank pumps stop automatically when then slats are extended for takeoff?

options.text: A: To keep the center of gravity as low as possible.
B: Dumping takeoff, the center tank fuel is pumped to the rear to trim aircraft
C: To ensure that the engines are fed from the wing tanks for takeoff (feeding segregation)
D: During takeoff, the center tank fuel is gravity fed only.

FUEL.question: 22: What precaution should you observe when gravity feeding fuel?

options.text: A: Operate the aircraft below 15,000 feet.
B: Use center tank first.
C: Open the crossfeed when above FL250
D: No precautions are necessary.

FUEL.question: 23: Refueling time at normal pump pressure is _____ minutes for the wing tanks and _____ minutes for all tanks.
24: After engine shutdown, what are your actions to close the fuel transfer valves?

options.text: A: You have to switch the inner tank pumps off.
B: You have to call maintenance to close the valves.
C: No action is required. The valves will close automatically during the next refueling.

FUEL.question: 25: Fuel can be transferred from tank to tank:

options.text: A: Only on the ground.
B: In flight if the fuel X FEED push button is selected OPEN.
C: In flight if the fuel X FEED push button is selected OPEN and center tank MODE SEL push button is selected to MAN.
D: Fuel can never be transferred.

FUEL.question: 26: How has the fuel been transferred from the outer to the inner tanks?

options.text: A: By setting the MODE SEL pushbutton to MAN.
B: The transfer valve has been opened automatically by the low lever sensor in the center tanks
C: By setting the MODE SEL PB to AUTO
D: The transfer valve has been opened automatically by the low level sensor in the inner tank.

FUEL.question: 27: What is the minimum fuel quantity for takeoff?

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 1: The flight control surfaces are _______ controlled and _______ actuated.

options.text: A: Electrically / hydraulically
B: Mechanically / hydraulically
C: Electrically / electrically

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 2: What computer normally commands the operation of the elevators and horizontal stabilizer?

options.text: A: SEC 1
B: FAC 1
C: ELAC 2

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 3: Sidesticks provide electrical signals to the flight control computers; if both sidesticks are operated:

options.text: A: The inputs cancel each other.
B: Both inputs are algebraically added.
C: The F/O input is overridden by the CAP input.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 4: Roll control is achieved by:

options.text: A: Ailerons
B: Ailerons and rudder.
C: One aileron and four spoilers on each wing.
D: Ailerons, rudder and spoilers

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 5: When the flaps are extended, the ailerons:

options.text: A: Go to the centering mode.
B: Pitch up 5 degrees.
C: Droop 5 degrees.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 6: If electrical power to a SEC fails:

options.text: A: The affected spoilers automatically retract.
B: All spoilers automatically retract.
C: The affected spoilers remains in the last commanded position.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 7: If angle of attack protection is active or flaps are in the configuration Full:

options.text: A: Speed brake extension is inhibited.
B: Aileron travel is reduced.
C: Speed brake extension travel is reduced.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 8: Should the active elevator actuator fail, elevator control is:

options.text: A: Lost.
B: Maintained by the other actuator.
C: Reduced.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 9: Two control surfaces that have mechanical backup are:

options.text: A: Elevator and rudder.
B: Horizontal stabilizer and rudder.
C: Speed brakes and rudder.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 10: Horizontal stabilizer trim automatically resets to zero degrees after landing.

options.text: A: True
B: False

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 11: Should both FACs fail, maximum rudder deflection can be obtained after the ______ are extended.

options.text: A: Flaps
B: Slats
C: Gear

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 12: Automatic rudder trim is provided at the rate of _____ while the manual rudder trim rate is ______ up to a maximum of ______.

options.text: A: 5 deg/sec - 2 deg/sec - 20 degs
B: 5 deg/sec - 1 deg/sec - 20 degs
C: 8 deg/sec - 2 deg/sec - 10 degs
D: 8 deg/sec - 5 deg/sec - 10 degs

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 13: Four hydraulically-operated wing tip brakes are installed to lock the flaps or slats in case of:

options.text: A: Asymmetry and overspeed only
B: Asymmetry, overspeed and slow movement
C: Asymmetry, overspeed, symmetrical runaway and uncommanded movement
D: All of the above

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 14: While on the ground in Roll Normal Law there is a direct relationship between sidestick deflection and the corresponding aileron and spoiler deflection

options.text: A: True
B: False

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 15: In Pitch Normal Law Flight Mode; pitch trim is:

options.text: A: Manual without the autopilot engaged.
B: Automatic as long as the autopilot is engaged.
C: Automatic with or without the autopilot engaged.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 16: In pitch normal law, the elevator control changes from the normal mode to a protection mode when the angle of attack is greater than:

options.text: A: Alpha Max
B: Alpha Prot
C: Alpha Floor

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 17: Automatic pitch trim is inhibited when:

options.text: A: Radio altitude is below 50 feet (100 feet with autopilot coupled).
B: Bank angle is greater than 33 degrees.
C: Load factor is less than 1G.
D: First two statements are correct

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 18: TOGA thrust is provided regardless of throttle position when _______ engages the autothrottle system.

options.text: A: Alpha Max
B: Alpha Prot
C: Alpha Floor

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 19: The purpose of the Load Alleviation Function is to:

options.text: A: Relieve wing structure loads by moving the ailerons.
B: Relieve wing structure loads by extending spoilers 4 and 5.
C: Help slow the airplane down.
D: First two statements are correct

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 20: With the aircraft in Pitch Alternate Law, roll is in _____ Law.

options.text: A: Direct
B: Normal
C: Alternate

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 21: In Pitch Alternate Law; the low Speed stability (nose down command) can be overridden by the sidestick.

options.text: A: True
B: False

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 22: When the landing gear is extended, pitch alternate law:

options.text: A: Remains the same.
B: Degrades to pitch direct law.
C: Degrades to pitch backup law.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 23: In the event of a complete loss of electrical flight control signals, the airplane reverts to a _______ mode.

options.text: A: Mechanical
B: Alternate Law
C: Alternate law
D: Abnormal Attitude law

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 24: To select speed brakes inflight:

options.text: A: Push down on the speed brake handle and move it forward.
B: Push down on the speed brake handle and move it aft.
C: Pull up on the speed brake handle and move it aft.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 25: Which of the following statements is correct concerning the spoiler elevator computers (SECs)?

options.text: A: Two computers which achieve spoiler control and standby elevator and THS control.
B: Three computers which achieve spoiler control and normal elevator and THS control.
C: Three computers which achieve spoiler control and standby elevator and THS control.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 26: The autopilot will disconnect if the side stick takeover push button is depressed.

options.text: A: True.
B: False

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 27: Which of the following statements are correct concerning the side stick takeover push button?

options.text: A: The last pilot to depress the push button has priority.
B: If the takeover push button is depressed for more than 40 seconds, the onside system will retain priority after the push button is released.
C: Both are correct.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 28: Are there any control surfaces with a mechanical backup?

options.text: A: Yes, the ailerons.
B: Yes, the spoilers
C: Yes, the THS and the rudder.
D: No, there aren’t any control surfaces with mechanical backup.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 29: What control surfaces do the FACs control?

options.text: A: The elevators.
B: The spoilers.
C: The rudder.
D: All of the above.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 30: Which of the following will automatically reset after landing?

options.text: A: THS.
B: Rudder trim.
C: Both are correct.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 31: What happens in the event of a single ELAC failure?

options.text: A: ELAC functions are transferred the SEC’s.
B: ELAC functions are transferred to FAC’s.
C: SEC functions are transferred the ELAC’s.
D: The functions of the failed ELAC will be assumed by the remaining ELAC.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 32: The alpha speed lock function:

options.text: A: Will inhibit flap retraction during an inadvertent movement of the flap selector at high AOA or low speeds.
B: Will inhibit slat retraction during an inadvertent movement of the flap selector at high AOA or low speeds.
C: Automatically raises the flaps if retraction has not been accomplished by 210kts.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 33: In normal law, if one stick is rapidly pulled fully back, can the aircraft’s maximum allowable G load be exceeded?

options.text: A: 'Yes. Rapid side stick deflection must never be made.
B: Yes, until maximum pitch attitude is reached.
C: No. At Maximum G load, the side sticks are de-activated for 5 seconds.
D: No. The load factor limitation overrides side stick commands to avoid excessive “G” loads.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 34: Which controls are used for the mechanical backup?

options.text: A: Ailerons and rudder.
B: THS and rudder.
C: Elevators and ailerons.
D: THS and elevator.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 35: Mechanically backed-up control surfaces:

options.text: A: Require hydraulic power for actuation
B: Are mechanically connected to the cockpit controls.
C: Both are correct.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 36: Selection of flaps one prior to takeoff will select which of the following?

options.text: A: Slats 1 and flaps 1 (1+F).
B: Slats 0 and flaps 1 (0+F).
C: Slats 1 and flaps 0 (1).
D: Slats 1 and flaps 5 (1).

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 37: Which of the following statements best describes the Load Alleviation function (LAF)?

options.text: A: Helps the pilot control the airplane.
B: Relieves wing structure loads by deflecting the ailerons and spoilers.
C: Relieve wing structure loads by deflecting only the spoilers.
D: Relieves wing structure loads by deflecting the ailerons.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 38: When ground spoilers deploy automatically:

options.text: A: All ten spoiler panels fully deploy.
B: Four spoiler panels on each wing deploy.
C: All ten spoiler panels deploy half way.
D: Six spoiler panels on each wing deploy.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 39: The FACs primarily control which control surface?

options.text: A: Elevator.
B: Rudder.
C: Aileron.
D: Elevator and aileron.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 40: Which altitude limitation is associated with high lift devices?

options.text: A: Max altitude for extension is 20, 000 ft.
B: Max altitude for extension is 22, 000 ft.
C: Max altitude for extension is 25, 000 ft
D: Max altitude for extension is 27, 000 ft.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 41: The message WING TIP BRK ON appears on the E/WD. What does it mean?

options.text: A: A hydraulic device locks the flaps in their present position.
B: To reduce structural stress, the slats movement is being slowed down through the wing tip brakes.
C: To avoid asymmetry, the outer slats are locked in their present position.
D: Because of the locked flaps, the wing tip brakes also lock the slats.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 42: Where does the SFCCs obtain AOA and air data information from?

options.text: A: SEC
B: ELAC
C: ADIRU
D: ADC

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 43: How many actuators are provided to control the ailerons and how many hydraulic sources supply these actuators?

options.text: A: 2 hydraulic sources with 4 actuators.
B: 1 hydraulic source with 2 actuators.
C: 4 hydraulic sources with 4 actuators.
D: 3 hydraulic sources with 4 actuators.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 44: If both FAC’s fail, what happens to the rudder limiter?

options.text: A: It immediately assumes the low speed position.
B: It freezes at its present position and assumes the low speed position when flaps 1 are selected
C: Maximum rudder deflection can be obtained after slats extended.
D: Maximum rudder deflection can be obtained after flaps extended.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 45: Which of the following statements is correct concerning the elevator aileron computers (ELAC’s):

options.text: A: Three computers which achieve normal elevator, stabilizer, and aileron control.
B: Two computers which achieve normal and standby control of the elevators, ailerons, and trimmable horizontal stabilizer.
C: Three computers which achieve normal and standby control of the elevators, ailerons, and THS.
D: Two computers which achieve normal elevator, stabilizer, and aileron control.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 46: The wing tip brakes, once activated:

options.text: A: Lock both the slats and flaps in their current position
B: Lock only the flaps in their current position.
C: Lock only the slats in their current position.
D: Lock only the affected high lift system surfaces in their current position

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 47: Which of the following controls and monitors flaps and slats?

options.text: A: Two ELAC’s.
B: Wing tip brakes.
C: One slat flap control computer (SFCC).
D: Two slat flap control computers (SFCCs).

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 48: The spoiler panels are the only flight control surfaces with no redundant control.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 49: What happens in the side stick-neutral high speed protection mode?

options.text: A: The autopilot disengages, bank angle limit is 30° and the aircraft is 25° roll limited.
B: The autopilot disengages, bank angle limit is 45° and the aircraft is 25° roll limited.
C: The autopilot disengages, bank angle limit is 40° and the aircraft rolls wings level and pitches up to slow down to VMO/MMO.
D: The autopilot disengages, bank angle limit is 35° and the aircraft rolls wings level and pitches to 10° to slow down to VMO/MMO - 20 kt.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 50: What is the maximum flap setting for in-flight use of the spoilers?

options.text: A: Flaps FULL.
B: Flaps 3.
C: Spoilers are not approved for in-flight use.
D: Flaps 10.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 51: What are the rudder trim rates?

options.text: A: A/P on - 5 deg/sec, A/P off - 1 deg/sec.
B: A/P on - 2 1/5 deg/sec, A/P off - 5 deg/sec.
C: A/P on - 3 deg/sec, A/P off - 6 deg/sec.
D: A/P on - 5 deg/sec, A/P off - 6 deg/sec.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 52: Can the crew make a flight control input that will over-stress the airplane in direct law?

options.text: A: No. The system is designed to avoid such an attempt.
B: Yes, there are no protections provided in direct law.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 53: Can you manually trim the rudder with the autopilot engaged?

options.text: A: Yes.
B: No.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 54: When is the Flight Mode active?

options.text: A: From takeoff until landing.
B: From liftoff until landing
C: From liftoff until flare mode engages at 50 ft RA.
D: From takeoff until passing 50 kts on landing (main shock absorbers depressed)

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 55: Automatic pitch trim is provided both on ground and in flight.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 56: The Ground Mode is different in Alternate Law.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 57: In normal law, what is the maximum bank angle you can reach with the side stick fully deflected?
58: Failure to retract the flaps after takeoff will:

options.text: A: Activate the wing tip brakes.
B: Result in automatic flap and slat retraction at 210 kts.
C: Result in automatic flap and slat retraction at 220 kts.
D: Result in automatic flap retraction at 210 kts.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 59: FAC generated slat and flap extension, retraction, and limiting speeds are visually displayed on which of the following?

options.text: A: The MCDU perf page.
B: The lower ECAM F/CTL page.
C: Both pilots PFD airspeed displays.
D: All of the above.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 60: Aileron droop may best be confirmed by checking which of the following?

options.text: A: The position of the ailerons on the exterior preflight inspection.
B: The lower ECAM FLT/CTL page.
C: The position of the flap handle.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 61: The wing tip brakes are:

options.text: A: Pneumatically actuated.
B: Electric brakes.
C: Hydraulically actuated.
D: Mechanically controlled, hydraulically actuated.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 62: Selection of flaps 1 in flight will select which of the following configurations?

options.text: A: Slats 1 and flaps 1 (1+F).
B: Slats 0 and flaps 1 (0+F).
C: Slats 1 and flaps 0 (1).
D: Slats 1 and flaps 5 (1+F).

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 63: The aircraft rudder can be manually trimmed with the autopilot engaged.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 64: What happens if you release the stick at 40 degrees of bank?

options.text: A: The bank stays at 40°
B: The aircraft rolls back to 25°
C: The aircraft rolls back to 33° and resumes flight path stability.
D: The aircraft rolls back to a bank angle less than 29°.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 65: When is alpha floor not available?

options.text: A: Out of normal law.
B: Below 100 feet RA in landing configuration.
C: If the A/THR is deactivated or unavailable.
D: All of the above.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 66: What kind of protections are provided if the aircraft is in Alternate Law?

options.text: A: G-load protection with a reduced factor.
B: Speed Stability
C: Full G load protection and speed stability
D: G-load protection and speed stability if the ADIRS and elevators are working.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 67: In Normal Law, what are the limits of Pitch Attitude protections with flaps Full

options.text: A: 30 nose up.
B: 35 nose up progressively reduced to 20°
C: 25 nose up, progressively reduced to 20° at low speed.
D: There is no limit.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 68: You can degrade directly from Normal Law to Direct Law with gear down and a dual radio altimeter fault.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 69: Turn coordination is available in Alternate Law.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 70: If both pilots deflect their side sticks fully back:

options.text: A: The pitch up order is twice as high as with only one stick deflected.
B: The pitch up order is 1.5 times higher as high as with only one stick deflected.
C: No inputs are sent to the flight control computers unless one pilot presses the takeover pushbutton on his stick.
D: The pitch up order is equal to a single stick deflection.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 71: To disable a side-stick, you have to depress the red take-over button on the active stick. Holding the button down for 40 seconds will electrically lock the other stick out until its own red take-over button is pushed again.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 72: Let’s assume the F/O presses his takeover pushbutton and releases it after more than 40 seconds.

options.text: A: The Captain’s side stick is de-activated unless he presses his takeover pushbutton.
B: The Captain is unable to re-activate his side-stick for the rest of the flight
C: Both sticks are active
D: The Captain’s side stick is active as long as the F/O’s side stick is in neutral position.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 73: What condition will cause auto flap retraction?

options.text: A: Exceed 210 kts at Flaps 1
B: Exceed 190 kt at Flaps 1.
C: Exceed 195 kt at Flaps 1
D: Exceed 190 kt with Flaps 1 while extending the speedbrake lever.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 74: What happens to the rudder limits if both FAC’s fault?

options.text: A: The limit freezes at the fault condition until Flaps 1 is selected.
B: The limit freezes at the fault condition until Flaps 5 is selected.
C: The limit freezes at the fault condition until Flaps 1 is selected. Then it resets to the low speed limits for increased control.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 75: What happens to high speed (VMO/MMO) when you are in Alternate Law?

options.text: A: VMO is reduced to 320 kt and MMO minus 10 kt.
B: VMO is reduced to 330 kt and MMO minus 10 kt
C: VMO is reduced to 320 kt and MMO does not change.
D: There is no change.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 76: Can the rudders be moved with both FAC’s inoperative?

options.text: A: Yes, if both FACs fail, maximum rudder deflection can be obtained when the slats are extended
B: Yes, if both FACs fail, maximum rudder deflection can be obtained
C: Yes, if both FACs fail, maximum rudder deflection can be obtained when the gear is extended or flaps extended at 1 minimum
D: No

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 77: The FLAP lever sends signal to Slat Flap Control Computer (SFCC) to command movement.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

FLIGHT CONTROLS.question: 78: Is there any rudder pedal feedback for the yaw damping and turn coordination functions?

options.text: A: Yes.
B: No.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 1: The avionics compartment is the only area where there is no fire extinguishing system installed.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 2: Engine fire loops are installed in the:

options.text: A: Pylon nacelle
B: Core
C: Fan
D: All the above

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 3: If a break in both engine fire loops occurs within _____ seconds of each other a _____ will occur.

options.text: A: 8 sec./ a FIRE warning
B: 7 sec./ a FIRE DET FAULT message on ECAM
C: 10 sec./ a FIRE DET FAULT message on ECAM
D: 5 sec./ a FIRE warning

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 4: The aircraft has dual fire detector loops to ensure that a fault in one fire loop will not affect fire detection capabilities.

options.text: A: True
B: False

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 5: If there is an APU fire in flight the APU:

options.text: A: Will automatically shut down and the fire bottle will discharge.
B: Must be shut down manually and the agent manually discharged.
C: Must be shut down manually but the fire bottle will discharge automatically.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 6: Fire protection for the cargo compartments includes:

options.text: A: Two fire bottles; one for each compartment.
B: One single shot fire extinguisher for the aft compartment only.
C: One single shot fire extinguisher agents which can be discharged to either compartment.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 7: The engine extinguishing agent switch is armed when:

options.text: A: The DISCH light is on.
B: The engine fire switch illuminates.
C: The engine fire switch is released out.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 8: When the APU FIRE SWITCH is released out:

options.text: A: The Fire bottle is discharged.
B: The Fuel HP valve is closed.
C: The APU bleed and crossbleed valves are closed.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 9: DISCH light on either the engine or APU fire agent switches indicates:

options.text: A: The APU or engine FIRE switch has been pushed.
B: The extinguisher bottle has been discharged.
C: A fault has occurred in the respective fire bottle.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 10: The GEN 1 LINE smoke light indicates:

options.text: A: A fire caused by number 1 generator.
B: Smoke in the avionics ventilation system.
C: Smoke in the cargo ventilation system.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 11: Can the APU FIRE test be performed using battery power only?

options.text: A: Yes.
B: No.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 12: When the aircraft is on the ground and the APU is started on battery power only, is fire protection available?

options.text: A: Yes, the APU will initiate an auto shutdown and discharge the extinguishing agent.
B: No, but the APU will initiate an auto shutdown.
C: No, automatic fire protection is only available if AC power is available.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 13: How many fire extinguishing bottles are available for fighting an APU fire?

options.text: A: One.
B: Two.
C: One cylinder shared with the aft cargo compartment.
D: Two cylinders shared with the aft cargo compartment.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 14: APU fire detection is accomplished by:

options.text: A: A two channel SDCU located in the APU compartment.
B: Two parallel fire detection loops.
C: One fire detection loop.
D: A three channel SDCU located in the APU compartment.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 15: Engine heat sensing are located in pylon nacelle, engine core and fan section.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 16: After an APU fire has been detected how long will the chime continue to sound?

options.text: A: Until the crew pushes the red MASTER WARN push button.
B: Until the crew pushes and releases the guarded red APU FIRE push button.
C: Both are correct.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 17: STATUS page: INOP SYS indicates “ENG1 LOOP B”.

options.text: A: One fire detection loop has failed. Fire detection for both engines is not available.
B: One detection loop for engine 1 has failed. Fire detection for both engines is still available.
C: One fire detection loop of engine 1 has failed. Fire detection for engine 1 is inoperative.
D: Both fire detection loops of engine 1 have failed. Fire detection for engine 1 is inoperative.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 18: Which of the following have automatic fire extinguishing systems?

options.text: A: APU, and lavatory waste bins.
B: APU, lavatory waste bins and avionics bay.
C: APU, aft cargo, forward cargo, lavatory waste bins and avionics bay.
D: APU, forward and aft cargo, lavatory and waste bins

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 19: The aft cargo compartment smoke detection system consists of:

options.text: A: A dual loop smoke detector.
B: Four smoke detectors and a two channel smoke detection control unit.
C: One smoke detector, one smoke detection control unit and two automatically discharging fire extinguishers.
D: Three smoke detectors, one smoke detection control unit and two automatically discharging fire extinguishers.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 20: If an engine fire is detected, when will the pedestal mounted red FIRE annunciator light extinguish?

options.text: A: When the crew pushes the red MASTER WARN push button.
B: Only after the fire warning no longer exists.
C: Only after the crew selects the adjacent ENG MASTER switch to off.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 21: How long will the red APU FIRE pb on the overhead be illuminated?

options.text: A: Until the crew pushes and releases the guarded red APU FIRE push button.
B: For as long as the fire warning is present.
C: Until the crew pushes the red MASTER WARN push button.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 22: With reference to cargo compartment fire extinguishing, which statement is true?

options.text: A: There are two fire bottles, one for the FWD compartment and one for the AFT.
B: There is only one fire bottle, pressing either DISCH pushbutton discharges it into both compartments.
C: There is only one fire bottle, when it is discharged both amber DISCH lights come on.
D: There are two fire bottles, when the DISCH pushbutton is pressed, they are both discharged into the appropriate compartment.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 23: Should you lose both loops or FDU, fire detection is no longer available for the respective engine or the APU

options.text: A: True
B: False.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 24: What is indicated by a missing red APU thermal plug during an exterior preflight?

options.text: A: This is normal indication, the red APU thermal plug only appears if the APU halon cylinder is low.
B: An APU fire agent thermal discharge has occurred.
C: An external fire discharge has been activated.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 25: If an engine fire is detected, when will the guarded red ENG FIRE push button light extinguish?

options.text: A: Only after the fire warning no longer exists.
B: When the crew pushes and releases the guarded red ENGINE FIRE pushbutton.
C: When the crew pushes the red MASTER WARN pushbutton.
D: When the crew pushes the red MASTER WARN pushbutton and then releases the guarded ENGINE FIRE pushbutton

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 26: In the event a lavatory smoke detector detects smoke:

options.text: A: Warnings will be generated only in the cockpit.
B: Warnings will be generated only on the flight deck.
C: warnings will be generated in the cockpit and in the cabin.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 27: Are there any warnings to alert ground personnel when there is a fire in the APU compartment?

options.text: A: Yes, but only if previously selected to automatic by the ground personnel.
B: No, APU fire indications are only present in the cockpit.
C: Yes, the external fire warning horn will sound and the APU red fire light will illuminate.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 28: What systems are affected when the guarded red ENGINE FIRE push button is pushed and released?

options.text: A: The Master Warning and the chime will be canceled and the AGENT pb’s will be armed.
B: All fluids, pneumatics and electrics relating to that engine are shut off
C: Both are correct.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 29: The avionics smoke detection system consists of the following:

options.text: A: A smoke detector, smoke detection control unit and one halon cylinder.
B: A smoke detector, and smoke detection control unit.
C: A smoke detector, heat detector, smoke detection control unit and one halon cylinder.
D: A smoke detector, smoke detection control unit and two halon cylinders.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 30: Will an APU fire test shut down the APU?

options.text: A: Yes.
B: No.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 31: Illumination of the GEN 1 LINE SMOKE light indicates:

options.text: A: A fire has been detected in the avionics compartment.
B: A satisfactory test of the avionics compartment smoke detection control unit.
C: Smoke has been detected in the avionics compartment ventilation duct.
D: A fire has been detected in the electronics compartment.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 32: In the event an aft cargo compartment smoke detector detects smoke:

options.text: A: Extinguishing is automatic.
B: Extinguishing is automatic only while on the ground.
C: The crew must depress the appropriate DISCH switch.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 33: How many halon fire extinguishing cylinders are there per engine?

options.text: A: Each engine has two fire extinguishers.
B: Each engine has it’s own dedicated fire extinguisher and has the capability to share the other engines cylinder.
C: Each engine has its own dedicated fire extinguisher and has the capability to share one centrally located halon cylinder.
D: Each engine has one fire extinguisher.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 34: The APU provides for automatic fire extinguishing:

options.text: A: On the ground only.
B: On the ground and in flight.
C: Only when selected to automatic by ground personnel.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 35: You have detected avionics smoke. You have selected the GEN 1 LINE push button off and the RAT has been deployed. Generator 2 has been removed from the system. Which of the following is TRUE?

options.text: A: The cargo fire bottle automatically fires.
B: The avionics fire bottle automatically discharges.
C: The aircraft will be in the Emergency Electrical Configuration

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 36: In conjunction with illumination of the GEN 1 LINE SMOKE light and MASTER CAUT light:

options.text: A: The BLOWER and EXTRACT push button FAULT lights will be illuminated.
B: Only the BLOWER FAULT light will be illuminated.
C: Only the EXTRACT FAULT light will be illuminated.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 37: After depressing the CARGO SMOKE TEST push button once, a satisfactory test of the aft cargo compartment smoke detector consist of:

options.text: A: Two complete cycles with associated warnings.
B: Not needed as this system self-tests during the first engine start.
C: One complete cycle with associated warnings.
D: Three complete cycles with associated warnings.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 38: How does the APU fire test on battery power differ from the APU fire test with all busses powered?

options.text: A: There is no difference.
B: While on battery power, only the red APU FIRE and AGENT/DISCH push button will illuminate.
C: It is not possible to test the APU fire protection while on battery power.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 39: If you perform the APU FIRE TEST with only DC power available, you get the MASTER WARN on the ECAM.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 40: In the event an aft cargo compartment smoke detector detects smoke:

options.text: A: Only an ECAM message will be generated.
B: Only a MASTER WARN and a CRC will be generated.
C: A MASTER WARN, CRC and an ECAM message will be generated.
D: A CRC and an ECAM message will be generated.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 41: During the walk-around, you have to check that the APU Fire extinguisher overpressure indication (green disc) is in place. This is an indication that the fire bottle has not been discharged.

options.text: A: True
B: False

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 42: The AFT SMOKE light closes the aft cargo inlet and outlet isolation valves and shuts off the aft cargo extraction fan.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 43: Each lavatory is equipped with:

options.text: A: Two smoke detectors and one smoke detection control unit.
B: One smoke detector and one smoke detection control unit.
C: One smoke detector, and for lavatory waste bins, an automatically discharging fire extinguisher.
D: Two smoke detectors and two automatically discharging fire extinguishers.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 44: Each engine nacelle and pylon area is equipped with:

options.text: A: Two fire detection loops.
B: A single fire detection loop.
C: Two smoke detectors and two fire detection loops.
D: A single fire detection loop and a single smoke detector.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 45: In addition to the CRC and red MASTER WARN light, a good engine fire test will display which of the following (AC power available)?

options.text: A: The CRC and red MASTER WARN light indicate a positive engine fire test.
B: Lower ECAM engine page, pedestal mounted red FIRE annunciator, red ENG FIRE push button and the AGENT SQUIB/DISC lights illuminate
C: E/WD red 1 (2) ENG FIRE warning, lower ECAM engine page, red FIRE annunciator, red ENG FIRE push button, and AGENT SQUIB/DISCH.

FIRE PROTECTION.question: 46: If an APU fire is detected on the ground, the APU shuts down automatically and the agent is discharged ______ after the warning is activated.

options.text: A: Immediately
B: 1 second.
C: 3 seconds.
D: 6 seconds.

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 1: The ______ on each wing are anti-iced with pneumatic bleed air.

options.text: A: Slats
B: Flaps
C: Three outboard slats

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 2: Electrical heating is provided for the protection of:

options.text: A: Pitots and Angle Of Attack (AOA) probes
B: Pitots, static ports and TAT probes
C: Pitots, static ports, AOA probes, and TAT probes.
D: Pitots and static ports

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 3: When a pneumatic leak is detected, the wing anti-ice valves:

options.text: A: Close automatically.
B: Open automatically.
C: Remain in position.

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 4: When either engine anti-ice valve is open:

options.text: A: Maximum N1 is increased.
B: Minimum idle rpm is increased.
C: Minimum idle rpm is reduced.

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 5: Window heat operates at what power level in flight?

options.text: A: Low
B: High

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 6: On the ground the wing anti-ice valves will:

options.text: A: Open during a test sequence (30 seconds); provided pneumatic supply is available.
B: Not open at anytime.
C: Open any time the switch is pushed “ON”.

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 7: Probe heat comes on automatically when:

options.text: A: The AC ESS bus is powered.
B: Electrical power is applied to the aircraft.
C: When at least one engine is running *

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 8: With reference to the PROBE/WINDOW HEAT pushbutton, which of the following is true?

options.text: A: The system should only be selected ON in icing conditions.
B: When in AUTO mode, the windows are heated only when necessary.
C: The system should only be selected ON after first engine start.
D: Window heating comes on automatically after first engine start

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 9: The drain masts are heated after first engine start.

options.text: A: True.
B: False

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 10: Where do the wing anti-ice indications appear on ECAM?

options.text: A: There is no indication on ECAM bleed page for wing anti-ice
B: An amber triangle appears on the ECAM bleed page
C: WING A.ICE appears on ECAM status page.
D: ANTI-ICE appears in white on the ECAM bleed page and W A.ICE appears in green on the ECAM memo when the wing P/B is pressed

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 11: The Fault light on the engine anti-ice switches indicates the valve:

options.text: A: Is closed.
B: Position disagrees with switch position.
C: Is open.

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 12: What is the difference between the engine and wing anti-ice fault lights?

options.text: A: Both indicate valve in transit, or valve position disagrees with selected position. Wing light also could indicate low pressure
B: Both indicate low pressure, or valve position disagrees with selected position. Wing light might indicate valve in transit.
C: Both indicate valve in transit, or low pressure. Wing light also could indicate valve position disagrees with selected position.
D: Both indicate valve in transit, or overheat

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 13: If one engine anti-ice system fails, the second one takes over and provides anti-icing for both engines.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 14: What happens when either engine anti-ice is open?

options.text: A: Maximum N1 is limited, continuous ignition is provided, maximum idle RPM is increased.
B: Maximum N1 is limited, continuous ignition is provided, minimum RPM is increased.
C: Minimum N1 is limited, continuous ignition is provided, minimum idle RPM is increased

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 15: In the event of loss of electrical supply the engine anti-ice valve:

options.text: A: Opens when the engine is shut down.
B: Closes when the engine is running.
C: Opens when the engine is running.
D: Open when the OAT is < 10 deg.C with the engine running

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 16: With the loss of electrical power the wing anti-ice valves:

options.text: A: Fail in their current position.
B: Fail to the open position.
C: Fail to the closed position.

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 17: What is the speed limit to operate the windscreen wipers?

options.text: A: 185 kts.
B: 200 kts.
C: 230 kts.
D: 250 kts.

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 18: In the event of an electrical power loss:

options.text: A: The engine anti-ice valves will open automatically, anti-icing is ensured.
B: The engine anti-ice valves will close automatically, anti-icing is lost.
C: The engine anti-ice valves will be controlled by the wing anti-ice controls.
D; The engine anti-ice valves remain in the position they were before.

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 19: At what power level does window heat operate while airborne?

options.text: A: High power while airborne.
B: Shifts from low to high as window temperature requires.
C: Low power above 18,000 ft.
D: Low power above 25,000 ft.

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 20: What happens to engine RPM when either engine anti-ice valve is open?

options.text: A: There is a fixed RPM increase.
B: The N1 limit for that engine is automatically increased.
C: The N1 limit for that engine is automatically reduced
D: There is a fixed RPM increase (3% of nominal N1)

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 21: Window heat operation begins:

options.text: A: Automatically after the first engine start.
B: if the PROBE/WINDOW HEAT push button is selected ON by the crew prior to engine start.
C: Both are correct.

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 22: Rain protection is provided by:

options.text: A: Warm bleed air blowing across the windshield.
B: Rain repellent and Windshield wipers.
C: Both are correct.

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 23: Can the wing anti-ice be tested on the ground?

options.text: A: Yes, with valves only open for 30 seconds.
B: Yes. Valves stay open till selected off.
C: No.

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 24: Anti-ice and de-icing protection is provided for:

options.text: A: The engine nacelle’s and three outboard wing slats.
B: The engine nacelle’s, the horizontal stabilizer, and three outboard wing slats.
C: The engine nacelle’s, the horizontal stabilizer, the vertical stabilizer and three outboard wing slats.

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 25: The probe heaters can be activated manually prior to engine start by placing the PROBE/WINDOW HEAT pushbutton.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 26: What happens to the heat at the drain masts when the aircraft is on the ground?

options.text: A: Nothing.
B: The heat is reduced to prevent injury to ground personnel.
C: Some of them are automatically switched off (pitot, AOA).

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 27: The RAIN RPLNT (rain repellent) pushbutton is inhibited on the ground when the engines stopped.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 28: TAT probes are heated on the ground.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 29: The ON light illuminates on the wing anti-ice P/B:

options.text: A: When the anti-ice valves open
B: When the P/B is set to ON
C: When the fault light goes out
D: When the anti-ice valves open and the fault light goes out.

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 30: How is window heating regulated?

options.text: A: Manually by flight crew
B: Window heat is not regulated!
C: One Window Heat Computer (WHC) as master, the other as slave
D: By two independent Window Heat Computers (WHC), one for each side

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 31: The Window Heat Computer provides two power levels for the windshield:

options.text: A: High power when above 20,000 ft, low power when below 20,000 ft
B: High power when OAT < 10 deg.C, low power when OAT> 10 deg.C
C: High power in flight, low power on the ground
D: High power in icing conditions (flight only), low power in other conditions.

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 32: The engine nacelle is anti-iced by:

options.text: A: Air bleed from the high pressure compressor
B: Air bleed from low pressure compressor
C: AC system and air bleed from low pressure compressor
D: DC system and air bleed from low pressure compressor.

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 33: When an engine anti-ice valve is open:

options.text: A: N1 limit is automatically reduced and the idle N1 is automatically increased
B: N2 of the associated engine is automatically decreased
C: N2 limit is automatically reduced and N1 limit is automatically increased
D: There is no change in the N1 and N2 limits.

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 34: In the event of a low air pressure:

options.text: A: The engine anti-ice valve opens automatically
B: There is no effect on the anti-ice valve position
C: The engine anti-ice valve must be manually closed
D: The engine anti-ice valve closes automatically

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 35: How can you check that engine anti-ice has been selected on?

options.text: A: You can observe the ON light on the associated engine anti-ice P/B and the ENGINE ANTI-ICE message on the ECAM engine page
B: You can observe the amber warning on the ECAM memo display and the amber anti-ice light on the overhead panel
C: You can observe the ENGINE ANTI-ICE message on the ECAM STATUS page
D: You can observe the blue ON light on the associated engine anti-ice P/B and the ENGINE ANTI-ICE memo on the E/WD

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 36: The electric windshield wipers are controlled:

options.text: A: Automatically when in heavy rain
B: By two individual pushbuttons
C: By one rotary selector for both windshields
D: By two individual rotary selectors

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 37: The wipers can operate at different speeds:

options.text: A: Low speed and high speed
B: Speed 1 and speed 2
C: Low, medium and high speed.
D: Speed is automatically adjusted depending on rain intensity.

ICE AND RAIN PROTECTION.question: 38: When the wiper is turned off:

options.text: A: The PARK position must be selected to stow the wiper
B: It continues to run for approximately 6 seconds
C: The wiper may stop in the pilots view
D: The wiper stops out of view

OXYGEN.question: 1: On which ECAM page could the flight crew check the exact pressure of the oxygen cylinder?

options.text: A: The PRESS page.
B: The DOORS page.
C: The COND page.
D: The STATUS page.

OXYGEN.question: 2: What is indicated by a missing green thermal plug during an exterior preflight?

options.text: A: An oxygen system overpressure or thermal discharge.
B: This is normal indication, the green thermal plug only appears if the oxygen cylinder is low.
C: The crew oxygen bottle is empty.
D: An external fire discharge has been activated.

OXYGEN.question: 3: Approximately how long are the passenger oxygen generators able to produce oxygen?

options.text: A: 15 minutes.
B: 20 minutes.
C:25 minutes.
D: 30 minutes.

OXYGEN.question: 4: What is the main difference between the crew and the passenger oxygen system?

options.text: A: There is no difference: both are served by oxygen cylinders.
B: Crew is supplied from an oxygen cylinder; passengers are supplied by chemical oxygen generators .
C: Both the crew and passengers are supplied with oxygen from chemical oxygen generators.
D: The crew has an oxygen bottle for an emergency back-up supply.

OXYGEN.question: 5: What is the purpose of the CREW SUPPLY push button?

options.text: A: When selected to ON, it supplies oxygen to the Captain & F/O only (jumpseats are not supplied)
B: When selected to ON, it allows the flow of low pressure oxygen to the crew’s masks.
C: In case of low cylinder pressure it allows the crew to tap into the passenger oxygen system.

OXYGEN.question: 6: What happens when the mask is used with the selection at 100% position?

options.text: A: Mask is supplied with diluted oxygen on demand.
B: Mask is supplied with undiluted oxygen on demand.
C: Mask is supplied with undiluted oxygen continuous flow.
D: Mask is supplied with diluted oxygen on demand.

OXYGEN.question: 7: At approximately what cabin altitude should the passenger oxygen masks drop?
8: What does an amber OXY on the ECAM Doors mean?

options.text: A: The crew supply switch is turned off and/or oxygen pressure is less than 400 psi *
B: The crew supply switch is turned off
C: Oxygen pressure is less than 650 psi.
D: Oxygen pressure is less than 300 psi.

OXYGEN.question: 9: Illumination of the SYS ON light is an indication that:

options.text: A: The crew must depress the MASK MAN ON pb in order to deploy the masks.
B: Electrical power has been sent to deploy the masks, either manually or automatically.
C: The crew oxygen cylinder is empty.
D: All of the passenger masks have deployed.

OXYGEN.question: 10: There are oxygen generators in each aircraft’s galley.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

OXYGEN.question: 11: What will depressing the guarded MASK MAN ON pb accomplish?

options.text: A: A signal is sent to the chemical oxygen generators to start the flow of oxygen to the masks.
B: It manually sends a signal to open the oxygen mask doors.
C: Both are correct.

OXYGEN.question: 12: When does passenger oxygen flow start?

options.text: A: When the mask is pulled toward the seat.
B: When the oxygen doors open.
C: When the oxygen button is pushed.
D: When cabin altitude exceeds 14,000 ft

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 1: The Flight Management part of the FMGC includes the following elements:

options.text: A: Navigation, flight planning and A/THR commands.
B: Performance optimization, A/THR and AP commands
C: Navigation, flight planning, performance optimization and flight predictions
D: AP and FD commands and flight envelope computation.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 2: How can the present position of the aircraft be initialized?

options.text: A: Present position can be entered through the ADIRS CDU.
B: Present position can be entered on the INIT page of the MCDU.
C: Both are correct.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 3: What are the correct positions for the PFD and ND?

options.text: A: The PFD should be outboard and the ND should be inboard.
B: The PFD should be inboard and the ND should be outboard.
C: The PFD should be to the left of the ND for both seat positions.
D: The PFD should be inboard and the ND should be inboard.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 4: What information is supplied by the IR’s and displayed on the PFD?

options.text: A: Heading, attitude, and vertical speed.
B: Heading, altitude, and vertical speed *
C: Airspeed, altitude, and backup vertical speed.
D: Heading, attitude, and altitude.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 5: How long does a normal IR alignment take?

options.text: A: Approximately 3 minutes.
B: Approximately 6 minutes.
C: Approximately 10 minutes.
D: Approximately 13 minutes.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 6: The IR ALIGN light is extinguished. What does this mean?

options.text: A: Alignment has been completed.
B: Air data output has been disconnected.
C: The respective IR is operating normally.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 7: An amber flashing IR FAULT light indicates that:

options.text: A: Present position needs to be reentered.
B: Attitude and heading information may be recovered in ATT mode.
C: A complete failure of the respective IR has occurred.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 8: What action should be taken if IR #2 is lost:

options.text: A: Move the EIS DMC rotary selector knob to F/O 3.
B: Move the ATT HDG rotary selector knob to CAPT 3.
C: Move the ATT HDG rotary selector knob to F/O 3.
D: Move the ATT HDG rotary selector knob to F/O 1.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 9: A/THR in white means that A/THR is:

options.text: A: Disconnected.
B: Armed.
C: Active

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 10: The white IR ALIGN light is flashing. What does this mean?

options.text: A: No present position has been entered and ten minutes has elapsed since the IR was selected ON.
B: No present position has been entered and ten minutes has elapsed since the IR was selected ON. An alignment fault may exist
C: Attitude and heading information have been lost. An alignment fault may exist.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 11: What message is displayed if the database effective date does not match the clock date?

options.text: A: Check Data Base Cycle.
B: Check Data Base Date.
C: Check Effective Date.
D: Check the changeover date.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 12: Placing one of the ADR push buttons OFF will accomplish what?

options.text: A: The OFF light will illuminate and air data output will disconnect.
B: The respective ADIRU will become deenergized.
C: Both AD and IR information will be disconnected.
D: All of the above.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 13: While in-flight, operating in Normal law, in the Alpha Prot range:

options.text: A: The flight controls revert to direct law.
B: The flight controls remain in the load factor demand law.
C: The sidestick controller and flight controls revert to the AOA mode, and side stick deflection is proportional to AOA.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 14: What is the difference between -FD2 and 2FD- on the FMA?

options.text: A: 1 inop, 2 engaged. 2 engaged, 1 off.
B: 1 off, 2 engaged. 2 engaged, 1 inop*

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 15: What does the LOW ACCURACY message mean?

options.text: A: FMGC 1 & 2 position difference exceeds limits.
B: FMGC position & actual radio position difference exceeds limits.
C: FMCG position & IR position difference exceeds limits.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 16: The thrust delivered by A/THR is already at MAX CLB thrust. Is it possible to obtain some additional thrust?

options.text: A: Yes, by setting a higher speed target.
B: Yes, by moving the thrust levers forward from the CL detent.
C: No, because the A/THR already delivers the maximum available thrust.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 17: What information is supplied by the Air Data Modules (ADMs) and displayed on the PFD’s?

options.text: A: Heading, attitude, and vertical speed.
B: Airspeed, altitude, and backup vertical speed.
C: Airspeed, vertical speed, and altitude.
D: Airspeed, attitude, altitude, and vertical speed.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 18: Can the autopilot be used for a single engine approach and autoland?

options.text: A: Yes.
B: No.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 19: During the takeoff phase:

options.text: A: SRS mode will provide guidance to maintain V2+10 kts (minimum) as a speed reference
B: SRS mode is available up to 1500 ft.
C: SRS mode will not engage if TOGA is selected.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 20: If the IR mode rotary selector is selected OFF:

options.text: A: AD and IR information will be disconnected.
B: AD information will be disconnected.
C: IR information will be disconnected.
D: The ADIRU is not energized: AD and IR information is lost.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 21: Which of the following statements is always true when operating in alternate law?

options.text: A: Extending the landing gear will place the aircraft in Direct law.
B: Extending the landing gear will place the aircraft in Mechanical backup law.
C: Extending the landing gear will place the aircraft in Mechanical backup law.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 22: Which protection is not available below 100 feet AGL?

options.text: A: Pitch attitude.
B: VLS.
C: ALPHA SPD (alpha speed)
D: Alpha floor.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 23: What does amber SPEED BRAKES mean on lower ECAM?

options.text: A: Speed brakes have a fault.
B: Speed brakes are extended and flap handle is not at 0.
C: Speed brakes are extended and engines are not at idle.
D: All of the above.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 24: If LOW ACCURACY message is displayed, are there any approach restrictions?

options.text: A: No
B: Yes, ILS approach only.
C: Yes, both LNAV and VNAV approaches are forbidden.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 25: The DDRMI provides the pilot with:

options.text: A: Bearing only for VOR 1.
B: Bearing and DME information for VOR 1 and ADF 1.
C: Bearing and DME information for VOR 2 and ADF 2.
D: Bearing only for VOR 1 and VOR 2.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 26: The ON BAT light will illuminate amber:

options.text: A: When one or more IR’s are operating on aircraft battery power.
B: For a few seconds at the beginning of the alignment process.
C: Both are correct.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 27: If both ELACs fail, what controls the elevator and stabilizer?

options.text: A: FACs.
B: SECs.
C: Elevator and stabilizer revert to mechanical backup.
D: Backup mode of ELAC’s

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 28: Where is the information displayed by DMC #1 and DMC #2?

options.text: A: DMC #1 supplies data to PFD #2, ND #2 and LOWER ECAM. DMC #2 supplies data for PFD #1, ND #1, and UPPER ECAM.
B: ADMC #1 supplies data to PFD #1, ND #1 and LOWER ECAM. DMC #2 supplies data for PFD #2, ND #2, and UPPER ECAM
C: DMC #1 supplies data to PFD #1, ND #1, and UPPER ECAM. DMC #2 supplies data for PFD #2, ND #2, and LOWER ECAM
D: DMC #1 supplies data to PFD #1, ND #1 and LOWER ECAM. DMC #2 supplies data for PFD #2, ND #2, and LOWER ECAM

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 29: While in flight operating in Normal law, movement of the sidestick and subsequent return to neutral will command:

options.text: A: A load factor proportional to stick deflection, then maintain one G flight corrected for pitch attitude.
B: Control surface movements proportional to stick deflection, then return the aircraft to straight and level flight.
C: Control surface movements proportional to stick deflection, disconnect auto trim, and maintain its current attitude.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 30: In normal law all protections are active, which of the following lists is the most complete list?

options.text: A: Protections, Load Factor, Pitch attitude, High AOA, and High speed.
B: Protections, Load Factor, Pitch attitude, High AOA, Alpha floor, angle of bank, and High speed.
C: Protections, Load Factor, Pitch attitude, High AOA, VLS, Alpha floor, and High speed.
D: Protections, Load Factor and Pitch attitude.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 31: When in alternate law, all protections except _______ protection will be lost.

options.text: A: Roll attitude.
B: Pitch attitude.
C: Bank angle.
D: Load factor.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 32: When does the sideslip indicator change to a blue Beta target?

options.text: A: Flaps configuration 1.
B: Any EPR exceeds 1.25, and EPR’s differ by more than 0.30 *
C: Heading differs from track by 20 deg or more
D: Flaps configuration 1, 2.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 33: High and low speed stabilities may be available in alternate law, stabilities:

options.text: A: Will not allow the pilot to stall the aircraft.
B: Prohibit steep bank angles.
C: Prohibit steep climb angles and bank angles.
D: Can be overridden by the pilot, and it is possible to exceed Vmo, Mmo and stall the aircraft.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 34: What is the function of the FACs?

options.text: A: Rudder and Yaw damping inputs, Flight envelope and speed computations
B: Rudder and Yaw damping inputs
C: Rudder and Yaw damping inputs and windshear protection
D: Rudder and Yaw damping inputs, Flight envelope and speed computations, and windshear protection

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 35: What causes a DU to display a black screen with a white diagonal line?

options.text: A: The circuit breaker for that particular DU has popped.
B: DMC failure.
C: No power.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 36: Can the aircraft be controlled with a loss of all electrics?

options.text: A: Yes.
B: No.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 37: The ATT HDG and AIR DATA selectors on the switching panel in the NORM position indicate that:

options.text: A: ADIRU 1 is supplying information to PFD 1 and ND 2, and ADIRU 2 is supplying power to PFD 2 and ND 1.
B: ADIRU 1 is supplying information to PFD 1, ND 1 and the DDRMI; ADIRU 2 is supplying power to PFD 2 and ND 2.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 38: What action should be taken if ADR #1 is lost?

options.text: A: Nothing.
B: Move the ATT HDG knob on the switching panel to CAPT 3.
C: Move the AIR DATA knob on the switching panel to CAPT 3.

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 39: How many Air Data/Inertial Reference Units (ADIRU’s) are installed?

options.text: A: One
B: Two
C: Three
D: Four

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 40: On an autoland approach, with both autopilots on, which FMGC is master?

options.text: A: FMGC 1
B: FMGC 2
C: Both

AUTOFLIGHT.question: 41: After a single DMC failure, how could a crewmember recover the display units?

options.text: A: Once a DMC has failed the information is unrecoverable
B: No action is needed as recovery is automatic.
C: Rotate the EIS DMC switch on the switching panel to replace the failed DMC with DMC #3.

AIRCONDITIONING PRESSURIZATION VENTILA.question: 1: Conditioned air is distributed to:

options.text: A: Cockpit, cargo bays and cabin
B: Cockpit, fwd and aft cabins
C: Cockpit, avionics bay and cabin
D: Cockpit, cabin and holds 1 and 2 only

AIRCONDITIONING PRESSURIZATION VENTILA.question: 2: Hot air fault light illuminates on the air conditioning panel,

options.text: A: The hot air press. reg. valve opens and the trim air valves close.
B: The hot air press. reg. valve closes and the trim air valves open.
C: The hot air press. reg. valve closes and the trim air valves close.
D: The hot air press. reg. valve opens and the trim air valves open.
