AIRCONDITIONING PRESSURIZATION VENTILA.question: 3: Does the trim air provide the warm air or the cold air to the air conditioning system?

options.text: A: Cold air
B: Warm air

AIRCONDITIONING PRESSURIZATION VENTILA.question: 4: In case of zone controller primary and secondary channel failure, what temperatures are maintained by pack one and pack two?

options.text: A: 15 deg C both
B: 25 deg C both
C: 20 deg C for pack one and 10 deg C for pack two
D: 24 deg C for pack one and 15 deg C for pack two

AIRCONDITIONING PRESSURIZATION VENTILA.question: 5: In normal flight in closed circuit configuration, the avionics ventilation system controls the temperature of the cooling air by:

options.text: A: Adding airconditioned air to the flow
B: Extracting air overboard
C: Adding avionics bay air
D: Passing air through a skin heat exchanger

AIRCONDITIONING PRESSURIZATION VENTILA.question: 6: To enable Ram air to the mixture unit, The Ram air switch should be used:

options.text: A: At any time
B: Only when differential pressure is less than 1 psi.
C: When pressure is greater than 1 psi diff.
D: Only after outflow valve is fully opened

AIRCONDITIONING PRESSURIZATION VENTILA.question: 7: Pack controller, primary channel failure.

options.text: A: The secondary computer operates as a backup mode and regulation is not optimized
B: The secondary computer takes over (all functions as normal)
C: Pack is lost
D: Pack outlet temperature is controlled at 15 deg C

AIRCONDITIONING PRESSURIZATION VENTILA.question: 8: Pack controller, secondary channel failure

options.text: A: No effect on pack regulation backup mode is lost
B: Pack is lost
C: No effect (all modes still available)
D: Pack outlet temperature is controlled at 15 deg C

AIRCONDITIONING PRESSURIZATION VENTILA.question: 9: Pack controller, primary and secondary channel failure

options.text: A: Pack outlet temperature is controlled to between 5 and 30 deg C by the anti-ice valve
B: The pack is closed
C: The packs deliver a fixed temperature of 20 deg C

AIRCONDITIONING PRESSURIZATION VENTILA.question: 10: Hot air pressure reg. valve failed open:

options.text: A: Optimized regulation is lost
B: The temperature stays at the value selected
C: No effect
D: Cabin temperature will be controlled at the upper limit 30 deg C

AIRCONDITIONING PRESSURIZATION VENTILA.question: 11: Bleed air supplied from the APU (APU bleed valve open), the pack flow is automatically selected:

options.text: A: High
B: Normal
C: Low
D: Econ. Flow

AIRCONDITIONING PRESSURIZATION VENTILA.question: 12: Trim air valve, each one optimizes the temperature by:

options.text: A: Adding hot air
B: Adding fresh air
C: Modulating of pack flow
D: Adding re-circulated air

AIRCONDITIONING PRESSURIZATION VENTILA.question: 13: Hot air pressure regulating valve:

options.text: A: Regulates the pressure of hot air tapped upstream of the packs
B: Is spring loaded open in the absence of air
C: Opens automatically in case of duct overheat
D: Opens automatically if the cabin trim air valve fails

AIRCONDITIONING PRESSURIZATION VENTILA.question: 14: Pack flow control valve:

options.text: A: Is pneumatically operated and electrically controlled
B: Electrically operated and pneumatically controlled
C: Opens automatically during engine starting
D: Is spring loaded to open.

AIRCONDITIONING PRESSURIZATION VENTILA.question: 15: Engine flow demand, when the heating or cooling demand in one zone cannot be satisfied:

options.text: A: The minimum idle must be increased manually
B: The minimum idle is increased automatically
C: In any case, flight idle is sufficient
D: The APU must be used to supply additional air.

AIRCONDITIONING PRESSURIZATION VENTILA.question: 16: What is the normal maximum cabin altitude?

options.text: D: 800 ft

AIRCONDITIONING PRESSURIZATION VENTILA.question: 17: What is the Max. negative Diff. pressure for the cabin?

options.text: A: 0 psi.
B: 1 psi.
C: 2 psi.
D: 8.6 psi.

AIRCONDITIONING PRESSURIZATION VENTILA.question: 18: It is permissible to use simultaneously packs and LP ground unit during long stops in a hot airfield

options.text: A: Yes
B: No
C: Yes, if external temperature is greater than 50 deg C

B: CAB reception knob and the MECH transmission key on the ACP.
C: Service Int on the nose gear panel.

COMMUNICATIONS.question: 43: To communicate with a mechanic for manual start valve operation at the engine:

options.text: A: Select the INT/RAD selector to INT, and INT audio selector on
B: Select the transmission key push button labeled INT and the INT audio selector.
C: Select the transmission key push button labeled CAB and the audio selector labeled CAB

COMMUNICATIONS.question: 44: Illumination of the SEL indicator on a Radio Management Panel indicates:

options.text: A: The RMP has failed.
B: The VHF has failed.
C: The RMP is being tuned to a transceiver from another RMP.

COMMUNICATIONS.question: 45: When would a green AM light illuminate on RMP 1?

options.text: A: Would not illuminate
B: If AM mode is required and crew has selected HF1 and AM
C: If crew has selected HF1 and single side band mode
D: If AM mode is required and crew has selected HF 2 and AM

COMMUNICATIONS.question: 46: A VOR is tuned on RMP 1 using the STBY NAV function. Can this selection be seen on the MCDU RAD NAV page?

options.text: A: No. Information on RAD NAV page is not available when the NAV pb on RMP is pressed.
B: Yes. Information on RAD NAV page is always available.
C: No. It is not possible to tune a VOR using STBY NAV function.
D: Yes. MCDU RAD NAV page shows VORs tuned using STBY NAV function.

COMMUNICATIONS.question: 47: Is it possible to tune a navaid with the STBY NAV function on RMP 3?

options.text: A: Yes
B: No. STBY NAV function is not available on RMP 3
C: No. RMP 3 is not available for crew use.
D: Yes but only on the ground.

COMMUNICATIONS.question: 48: How can a navaid tuned through the STBY NAV on RMP 1 or 2 be identified?

options.text: A: The ident appears on the ND
B: By pressing out the corresponding reception knob on the ACP
C: All of the above.

COMMUNICATIONS.question: 49: If an RMP fails:

options.text: A: The selected receiver is no longer controlled by this RMP
B: The frequency displays disappear
C: The green VHF or HF lights go out
D: All of the above.

COMMUNICATIONS.question: 50: With the MECH transmission key on the Audio Control Panel pressed:

options.text: A: The flight interphone channel is selected for transmission via the ACP RAD switch or the side stick radio selector.
B: The cabin interphone channel is selected for transmission via the ACP RAD switch
C: You can speak to the ground mechanic via the handset
D: The mechanic will hear the external horn sound.

COMMUNICATIONS.question: 51: How could you receive ATIS information from a VOR?

options.text: A: Pressing the ON voice key on the ACP
B: Pressing and releasing out the VOR reception knob and selecting the ON voice key on the ACP
C: Voice facility is not available through the ACP
D: None of the above.

COMMUNICATIONS.question: 52: How do you cancel the ON VOICE green light?

options.text: A: By depressing the on voice p/b
B: By pressing in the VOR reception knob
C: By pressing in twice the VOR reception knob
D: By depressing the VOR reception knob.

COMMUNICATIONS.question: 53: Once activated, how can you cancel the EVAC alert from the cockpit?

options.text: A: OFF switch.
B: Only able to deactivate from cabin (#1 Flight attendant).
C: COMMAND switch.
D: HORN SHUT OFF

HYDRAULICS.question: 1: Fluid can be transferred between hydraulic systems.

options.text: A: True
B: False

HYDRAULICS.question: 2: Which hydraulic systems have engine driven pumps?

options.text: A: Green and blue.
B: Green and yellow.
C: Blue and yellow.

HYDRAULICS.question: 3: The Load Alleviation Function (LAF) accumulators are pressurized by which hydraulic systems?

options.text: A: Green and blue.
B: Green and yellow.
C: Blue and yellow.

HYDRAULICS.question: 4: The RAT pressurizes the Blue hydraulic system to approximately ______ psi.
5: How many pumps has the yellow system to provide pressure (not counting the PTU)?
6: The hand pump supplies yellow system pressure to the:

options.text: A: Normal brakes.
B: Alternate brakes
C: Passenger doors.
D: Cargo doors.

HYDRAULICS.question: 7: It is possible to pressurize the green hydraulic system on the ground via the PTU when the parking brake is set.

options.text: A: True
B: False

HYDRAULICS.question: 8: The Eng Pump Fault light extinguishes when the engine pump switch is selected to off except for:

options.text: A: Reservoir low level.
B: Pump low pressure.
C: An overheat.

HYDRAULICS.question: 9: With the airplane on the ground and the blue electric pump switch in AUTO; the blue pump will be energized when:

options.text: A: One engine is running.
B: The BLUE PUMP OVRD switch has been pressed.
C: First two statements are correct.

HYDRAULICS.question: 10: The PTU Fault light illuminates when the:

options.text: A: PTU is inoperative.
B: Green or yellow reservoir has low air pressure.
C: PTU pump has overheated.

HYDRAULICS.question: 11: The PUMP identification number on the ECAM HYD page becomes amber when:

options.text: A: System pressure is below 1450 psi.
B: N2 is below idle.
C: The reservoir level is low.

HYDRAULICS.question: 12: The _____ hydraulic system provides power for gear extension/retraction.

options.text: A: Yellow.
B: Blue
C: Green

HYDRAULICS.question: 13: As long as the landing gear lever is up a hydraulic safety valve closes to cut off the hydraulic supply to the gear when the airspeed is:

options.text: A: Greater than 260 KIAS.
B: Greater than 230 KIAS.
C: Less than 260 KIAS.
D: Less than 230 KIAS

HYDRAULICS.question: 14: Autobraking is initiated by:

options.text: A: Strut compression.
B: Reverser action.
C: Ground spoiler extension command.

HYDRAULICS.question: 15: When using the alternate brake system on accumulator pressure only; the accumulator supplies:

options.text: A: Partial brakes.
B: At least seven full brake applications.
C: Alternate brakes with antiskid.

HYDRAULICS.question: 16: The maximum degrees of nosewheel steering available when using the handwheel is ______.
17: The green DECEL light on the Autobrake switch illuminates when the actual airplane deceleration corresponds to ______ % of the selected rate.
18: The brakes pressure indication on TRIPLE PRESSURE INDICATOR reads which system pressure?

options.text: A: Yellow
B: Blue
C: Green

HYDRAULICS.question: 19: To extend the landing gear with the Gravity Extension Handcrank requires _______ turns of the handle.

options.text: A: 3 counter-clockwise
B: 2 counter-clockwise
C: 3 clockwise

HYDRAULICS.question: 20: The aircraft’s three hydraulic systems are normally pressurized by:

options.text: A: Two engine driven pumps and one electric pump.
B: Two electric pumps and one PTU.
C: Two electric pumps and one engine driven pump.
D: Two electric pumps and two engine driven pumps.

HYDRAULICS.question: 21: When will the yellow system electric pump operate? (AC power is available).

options.text: A: During the second engine start.
B: When the first engine MASTER switch is moved to the ON position.
C: If any N2 RPM is less than 45%.
D: When the yellow electric system ELEC PUMP push button is selected to ON or the ground crew activates a cargo door switch

HYDRAULICS.question: 22: What are the major equipment losses with loss of Green system?

options.text: A: Speed Brakes.
B: Nosewheel steering, Autobrakes
C: Alternate Brakes.
D: The upper and lower rudders.

HYDRAULICS.question: 23: The hydraulic PTU will activate if:

options.text: A: A significant pressure loss occurs in any of the three hydraulic systems.
B: A significant pressure loss occurs in the green or yellow hydraulic system.
C: Both are correct.

HYDRAULICS.question: 24: After extending the RAT, is it possible to check its position and status?

options.text: A: Check to see if the blue system ELEC PUMP FAULT light is not illuminated.
B: Yes, select the ECAM ELEC page.
C: Yes, select the ECAM HYD page.
D: No. It is not possible.

HYDRAULICS.question: 25: The RAT is capable of powering a pump which will pressurize:

options.text: A: Only the blue system.
B: All systems.
C: The blue and yellow system.
D: The blue and green system.

HYDRAULICS.question: 26: How is the yellow hydraulic system pressurized?

options.text: A: An engine driven pump, an electric pump, the PTU using the green system and, for the cargo doors only, a hand pump.
B: An engine driven pump, electric pump, the PTU using the blue system and, for the cargo doors only, a hand pump.
C: An engine driven pump, an electric pump, and the PTU using the green system.

HYDRAULICS.question: 27: When will normal operation of the BLUE system hydraulic pump begin?

options.text: A: During the first engine start.
B: When the first engine MASTER switch is moved to the ON position.
C: Only when the RAT is deployed.
D: After both engines are started.

HYDRAULICS.question: 28: The PTU comes into action automatically when the differential pressure between the GREEN and the YELLOW systems is greater than ______ psi.
29: When will the yellow system electric pump operate? (AC power is available)

options.text: A: During the second engine start.
B: When the yellow electric system ELEC PUMP push button is selected to ON or the ground crew activates a cargo door switch.
C: If any N2 RPM is less than 45%.
D: When the first engine MASTER switch is moved to the ON position.

HYDRAULICS.question: 30: What is the normal pressure in the hydraulic system?

options.text: A: 500 psi.
D: 2,000 psi

HYDRAULICS.question: 31: You are at the gate. You have started engine #2. Before starting engine #1, you notice that the PTU test has not been activated. Is it normal?

options.text: A: No. You have to call the mechanics.
B: The PTU has been shutoff
C: The PTU will not work until the second engine has been started.

HYDRAULICS.question: 32: You get a G RSVR OVHT message. Why does the ECAM procedure ask you to switch the PTU off first?

options.text: A: To prevent the hot hydraulic fluid from being transferred to the YELLOW system.
B: To depressurize the YELLOW and GREEN systems.
C: To prevent the BLUE system from pressurizing the GREEN system.
D: To prevent the PTU from pressurizing the GREEN system

HYDRAULICS.question: 33: For hydraulic system malfunctions, when will the RAT deploy?

options.text: A: Automatically with the failure of both the green and blue hydraulic systems.
B: Automatically with the failure of both the green and yellow hydraulic systems.
C: Only when the guarded RAT MAN ON push button is selected by the crew.
D: When airspeed drops below 100 knots with the gear up.

HYDRAULICS.question: 34: What does the RAT MAN ON switch do?

options.text: A: Extends RAT, pressurizes BLUE system, starts Emergency Generator.
B: Extends RAT, must push RAT MAN ON again to pressurize BLUE system.
C: Extends RAT, pressurizes GREEN system, starts Emergency Generator.
D: Extends RAT, pressurizes BLUE system, does not start Emergency Generator.

HYDRAULICS.question: 35: Describe the PTU status with a green system reservoir overheat, low pressure or low fluid level.

options.text: A: The PTU will be inhibited
B: The crew must select the PTU ON.
C: The PTU fault light will remain illuminated as long as the problem exists. The PTU should be selected OFF.
D: The crew must select the PTU OFF then ON

HYDRAULICS.question: 36: During engine start up, when is the BLUE hydraulic system pressurized?

options.text: A: As soon as the PTU is turned on.
B: As soon as the BLUE electric pump is manually turned on.
C: Automatically after first engine start.
D: As soon as the engine master switch is set to IGN/START

HYDRAULICS.question: 37: If you lost the GREEN system, what equipment is lost?

options.text: A: Reverser 1 and gear retraction.
B: Reverser 1, gear retraction and nose wheel steering
C: Reverser 2, gear retraction, cargo doors and nose wheel steering.
D: Reverser 2 and gear retraction.

HYDRAULICS.question: 38: Crew members can use a hand pump to pressurize the YELLOW system in order to operate the cargo doors when no electrical power is available.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

HYDRAULICS.question: 39: If you lost the YELLOW system, what equipment is lost?

options.text: A: Reverser 2
B: Parking brake accumulator recharging
C: Cargo door.
D: All of the above.

HYDRAULICS.question: 40: On the hydraulic quantity indicator what does the amber level indicate?

options.text: A: The warning level.
B: The reservoir contents
C: The normal filling level
D: The temperature of the hydraulic fluid.

HYDRAULICS.question: 41: What does a PTU FAULT light indicate?

options.text: A: GREEN or YELLOW reservoir overheat.
B: GREEN or YELLOW reservoir low air pressure.
C: GREEN or YELLOW reservoir low level.
D: All of the above.

HYDRAULICS.question: 42: If you lost the BLUE system, what equipment is lost?

options.text: A: The Emergency generator.
B: Cargo door
C: Nose wheel steering.
D: All of the above.

HYDRAULICS.question: 43: All hydraulic systems have a fire shutoff valve.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

HYDRAULICS.question: 44: What is the signification of an amber RAT indicator (ECAM HYD page)?

options.text: A: The RAT is incorrectly stowed.
B: The RAT is not stowed.
C: Pressure for stowing the RAT has been applied, or the RAT pump is not available.

HYDRAULICS.question: 45: How can the pilot switch off the Fire Shut Off Valves?

options.text: A: By de-pressing the Hydraulic Shut Off Switches.
B: By selecting the Hydraulic Valve Switch to the “Closed” position
C: By de-pressing the Engine Fire Switches

HYDRAULICS.question: 46: If the Landing Gear was gravity extended using the hand crank on the center pedestal, what other systems will be inoperative?

options.text: A: Nose wheel steering and auto braking
B: Nose wheel steering only.
C: Anti-skid and auto braking.
D: Nose wheel steering and anti-skid.

LANDING GEAR.question: 1: Which hydraulic system(s) supply pressure to the landing gear system?

options.text: A: Green
B: Blue
C: Yellow and Blue
D: Green and Blue.

LANDING GEAR.question: 2: The braking modes are:

options.text: A: Green with anti-skid, Yellow without anti-skid, Parking brake.
B: Green or Yellow with anti-skid, Yellow without anti-skid, parking brake
C: Green with or without anti-skid, Blue without anti-skid

LANDING GEAR.question: 3: If the brake system automatically transitions to alternate brakes with the A/SKID & N/W STRG switch in the ON position, which of the following will be available?

options.text: A: Auto brakes and anti-skid.
B: Only auto brakes.
C: Brakes, auto brakes, anti-skid.
D: Anti-skid.

LANDING GEAR.question: 4: What is indicated by the autobrake DECEL lights?

options.text: A: Airplane deceleration is 25% of selected rate.
B: Airplane deceleration is 50% of selected rate.
C: Airplane deceleration is 100% of selected rate.
D: Airplane deceleration is 80% of selected rate.

LANDING GEAR.question: 5: On the E/WD, you notice the NW STRG DISC memo. What does it mean?

options.text: A: The nose wheel steering has been disconnected by ground personnel.
B: A failure in the nose wheel steering system has been detected.
C: There is a discrepancy between the two nose wheel steering handwheel positions
D: The nose wheel steering computer has finished its self test.

LANDING GEAR.question: 6: During pushback, you start engine #2. You observe the NW STRG DISC memo has changed to amber. Why?

options.text: A: The NW STRG disconnect mechanism has failed.
B: The yellow hydraulic system is now pressurized and the amber caption is a warning not to move the handwheel
C: The nose wheel steering is being reconnected by ground personnel. It is amber because the pin is removed.
D: The memo has become amber because one engine is running.

LANDING GEAR.question: 7: Landing Gear position is indicated by:

options.text: A: One panel on center instrument panel, one panel on overhead panel
B: ECAM only
C: One panel on center instrument panel and ECAM
D: One panel on center instrument panel, ECAM, visual means on the wing.

LANDING GEAR.question: 8: If the landing gear was gravity extended using the hand crank on the center pedestal, landing gear position must be verified through:

options.text: A: The landing gear viewers.
B: The landing gear indications depicted on the ECAM and, if available, the center panel LDG GEAR indicator panel lights.
C: Both are correct.

LANDING GEAR.question: 9: Landing gear operation is inhibited at speeds:

options.text: A: Below 100 knots.
B: Above 260 knots +/- 5 knots.
C: below 100 knots and above 260 knots.
D: Above 250 knots.

LANDING GEAR.question: 10: Can the gear be extended above 260 kts if necessary?

options.text: A: Never.
B: Yes, but only manually
C: Yes, but the ultimate limit is 285 kt CAS

LANDING GEAR.question: 11: How can the brake accumulator be re-pressurized?

options.text: A: With the yellow electric hydraulic pump.
B: With the blue electric hydraulic pump.
C: Both are correct.

LANDING GEAR.question: 12: You are ready to taxi. You apply the toe brakes on the rudder pedals and release the PARK BRK. The BRAKES pressure falls to zero. What should you do?

options.text: A: This should not happen and you must assume that the BRAKES pressure indicator has failed.
B: Nothing as this is normal. The BRAKES pressure indicator only indicates alternate (yellow) brake pressure.
C: You must re-apply the PARK BRK and call for maintenance personnel as the main system pressure has failed.
D: The indication is normal because once the AUTO BRK is set to MAX the BRAKES indicator is by-passed.

LANDING GEAR.question: 13: Which hydraulic system supplies pressure to the nose wheel steering?

options.text: A: Green
B: Blue
C: Green and Blue.
D: Yellow.

LANDING GEAR.question: 14: The antiskid deactivates when ground speed is less than ______.

options.text: A: 10 kts.
B: 20 kts.
C: 25 kts.
D: 30 kts.

LANDING GEAR.question: 15: If the BSCU detects a brake system malfunction in flight with the A/SKID & N/W STRG switch in the ON position:

options.text: A: The crew will be notified with an ECAM message after touchdown if the brake system does malfunction.
B: The crew will be notified with an ECAM message.
C: The crew must manually select alternate brakes.
D: All of the above.

LANDING GEAR.question: 16: What is required to arm the auto brakes?

options.text: A: Green hydraulic pressure available, anti-skid, no failures in the braking system.
B: Landing gear lever selected down and selection of an autobraking rate.
C: Both are correct.

LANDING GEAR.question: 17: What does each turn of the gravity gear extension handle do?

options.text: A: Open gear doors, unlock gear, drop gear.
B: Open gear doors, drop gear, shut doors.
C: Shutoff hydraulic pressure, open doors, unlock gear.
D: Open gear doors, shutoffs hydraulics, unlock gear, drop gear.

LANDING GEAR.question: 18: How many turns are required on the gravity extension hand crank to extend the landing gear?
19: How do you manually extend the landing gear?

options.text: A: Lift the red handle and turn anticlockwise 4 turns.
B: Lift the red handle and turn anticlockwise a minimum of 2 turns.
C: Lift the red handle and turn clockwise a minimum of 4 turns.
D: Lift the red handle and turn clockwise by 3 turns.

LANDING GEAR.question: 20: Auto brake may be armed with the parking brake on.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

LANDING GEAR.question: 21: Can normal landing gear operation be restored after a gravity extension if green hydraulic pressure is available?

options.text: A: Restoration is always possible.
B: It may be possible if the gravity extension was not caused by a failure of the landing gear mechanism.
C: No, only maintenance can restore normal operation.

LANDING GEAR.question: 22: When the landing gear is gravity extended, will nose wheel steering be available?

options.text: A: Only if the A/SKID & N/W STRG switch is selected ON.
B: No
C: Limited nose wheel steering is available only through the captain’s rudder pedals.

LANDING GEAR.question: 23: Auto brakes, if selected, will only be activated by:

options.text: A: The wheels spinning up.
B: The struts being compressed.
C: The brake pedals being depressed.
D: The ground spoiler extension command.

LANDING GEAR.question: 24: There are two triangles for each gear on the ECAM WHEEL page. What do they represent?

options.text: A: Each triangle represents one wheel on the gear.
B: Each triangle represents the position detected by one of the two computers systems.
C: Each triangle represents one of the braking systems available for that gear.
D: The front triangle indicates the position of that gear and the back triangle indicates the status of the brakes for that gear.

LANDING GEAR.question: 25: What system pressure does the ACCU PRESS and BRAKES pressure indicator indicate?

options.text: A: Yellow brake accumulator and yellow brake system pressure to the left and right brakes.
B: Yellow brake accumulator and green brake system pressure to the left and right brakes.
C: Yellow brake accumulator and green or yellow brake system pressure to the left and right brakes.
D: Blue brake accumulator and green brake system pressure to the left and right brakes.

LANDING GEAR.question: 26: The normal brake system uses _____ hydraulic pressure and the alternate brake system uses _____ hydraulic pressure backed up by the hydraulic brake accumulator

options.text: A: Green _ Blue
B: Yellow _ Blue
C: Yellow _ Green
D: Green _ Yellow.

LANDING GEAR.question: 27: Wheel page of ECAM: if you see a green arc shown over a wheel indication:

options.text: A: It marks the hottest brake with a temperature of more than 100°C.
B: It indicates an abnormal high temperature.
C: The A/SKID system is automatically releasing the pressure of that brake.
D: The L/G control system has detected a low tire profile.

LANDING GEAR.question: 28: Nose wheels and main wheels have fusible plugs that prevent the tires from bursting if they overheat.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

LANDING GEAR.question: 29: With the A/SKID & N/W STRG switch in the ON position, if the BSCU detects a brake system malfunction and/or normal braking is not available

options.text: A: The crew will be notified with an ECAM message only if after touchdown the brake system does actually malfunction.
B: Transition to the alternate brake system is automatic.

LANDING GEAR.question: 30: You have just set the parking brake handle to ON. Is it still possible to check the main brake system using the toe brakes?

options.text: A: Yes. As soon as you press the brake pedals the BRAKES indicator will read main system pressure.
B: No. It is not possible to press hard enough to obtain an accurate reading.
C: No. When the PARK BRK is set, the other braking modes are deactivated.

LANDING GEAR.question: 31: If the accumulator on the alternate brake system is your only source pressure, which of the following will be available?

options.text: A: Auto brakes and antiskid.
B: Antiskid.
C: Seven applications of the brake pedals.
D: Three applications of the brake pedals

LANDING GEAR.question: 32: The gear doors remain open after a manual extension.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

LANDING GEAR.question: 33: The steering handwheels, which are interconnected, can steer the nose wheel up to _____ in either direction.

options.text: A: 55deg.
B: 65deg
C: 75deg
D: 90deg

LANDING GEAR.question: 34: The green DECEL light on the autobrake pushbutton illuminates when the actual airplane deceleration corresponds to what percentage of the selected rate?
35: Each main wheel has an antiskid brake.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

LANDING GEAR.question: 36: The parking brake accumulator is designed to maintain the parking pressure for at least ______.

options.text: A: 6 hours.
B: 12 hours.
C: 18 hours.
D: 24 hours.

LANDING GEAR.question: 37: The autobrake will arm if at least one ADIRS is functioning

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

LANDING GEAR.question: 38: What happens to the other brake modes when parking brakes are applied?

options.text: A: There is no change.
B: All other braking modes and antiskid are deactivated.
C: Antiskid mode only is deactivated.

LANDING GEAR.question: 39: Maximum speed for landing gear retraction is:

options.text: A: 200 kts
B: 220 kts
C: 235 kts
D: 250 kts

LANDING GEAR.question: 40: Nose wheel steering is available when:

options.text: A: Gear doors open
B: All gear doors closed
C: The Push button on either steering hand wheel is depressed
D: Nose gear doors closed

LANDING GEAR.question: 41: Nose wheel steering is controlled by:

options.text: A: LGCIU 1.
B: BSCU
C: LGCIU 2
D: LGCIU 1 or 2

LANDING GEAR.question: 42: When is pressure in the nose wheel steering system shut off?

options.text: A: With towing lever in towing position or both engines are shut down or the A/SKID & N/W STRG switch is OFF
B: During ground towing with one engine shut down or when aircraft speed is >60 kts
C: When the aircraft is on the ground with speed above 100 kts

LANDING GEAR.question: 43: Hand wheel and pedals are operated simultaneously:

options.text: A: Hand wheel has priority
B: Pedals have priority (depending on speed)
C: BSCU transforms these orders into nose wheel steering angle (signals are mathematically added)
D: Hand wheel input will not be affected by pedals.

LANDING GEAR.question: 44: Nose wheel steering by rudder pedals is limited to:

options.text: A: +/- 6 degrees under all conditions
B: +/- 75 degrees
C: +/- 90 degrees
D: Maximum +/- 6 degrees depending on aircraft speed

LANDING GEAR.question: 45: When both hand wheels are operated simultaneously, the signals:

options.text: A: From the first pilot acting on his hand wheel have priority
B: Coming from the captain have priority
C: Are algebraically added
D: From the F/O have priority

LANDING GEAR.question: 46: Nose wheel steering is available:

options.text: A: Aircraft speed below 70 kts, both engines (required to be) running, Towing lever in normal position, aircraft on ground.
B: Aircraft speed below 70 kts, both engines (required to be) running, Towing lever in normal position, aircraft on ground or in the air
C: Aircraft speed below 70 kts, one engine (required to be) running, Towing lever in normal position, aircraft on ground.
D: Aircraft speed below 70 kts, both engines (required to be) running), Towing lever in standby position, aircraft on ground.

LANDING GEAR.question: 47: After T/O the left main landing gear shock absorber is stuck in the compressed position.

options.text: A: The gear can be retracted under all circumstances
B: The gear cab be retracted provided the nose gear is centered
C: The gear cannot be retracted; gear lever is blocked (interlock mechanism)
D: The gear can be retracted once the nose wheel steering is centered

LANDING GEAR.question: 48: Is it possible (system wise) to lower the gear by gravity above 260 kts?

options.text: A: Yes
B: No
C: Yes, but only if green hydraulics available
D: Yes, but only if yellow hydraulic available

LANDING GEAR.question: 49: System page “Wheel”. L/G position indicators (triangles), first line shows green triangles, second line behind shows amber crosses. Is the landing gear down?

options.text: A: Yes
B: No
C: Right hand gear only is down
D: Left hand gear only is down.

LANDING GEAR.question: 50: During the approach you get master warning and ECAM “Gear Not Down”. The reason is:

options.text: A: Landing gear is not down locked and flaps 3 or full and both radio altimeters failed
B: Landing gear is not down locked, flaps at 3 and radio height lower than 750 ft
C: All of the above
D: None of the above.

LANDING GEAR.question: 51: The alternate brake system uses:

options.text: A: The Yellow hydraulic system
B: The hydraulic accumulator
C: The Yellow hydraulic system and the hydraulic accumulator
D: The Blue electric pump.

LANDING GEAR.question: 52: The antiskid system gets its reference speed from:

options.text: A: The ADIRS
B: A wheel tachometer
C: The LGCIU’s
D: The BSCU’s

LANDING GEAR.question: 53: The principle of the anti-skid is:

options.text: A: Comparing the speed difference between the four wheels
B: Comparing wheel speeds with aircraft reference speed
C: Comparing wheel speeds between left and right landing gear
D: Comparing left and right wheel speeds on the same landing gear.

LANDING GEAR.question: 54: Following failure of all 3 ADIRS, is antiskid available?

options.text: A: Yes
B: No
C: Only with Yellow hydraulics
D: Only with Green hydraulics

LANDING GEAR.question: 55: Alternate braking using the Yellow system. Autobrake is:

options.text: A: Lost
B: Still available with anti-skid
C: Still available without anti-skid
D: Still available provided Yellow system hydraulic pressure is available.

LANDING GEAR.question: 56: Autobraking is initiated by:

options.text: A: Reverse thrust selection
B: Nose gear oleo compression
C: Main gear oleo compression
D: Ground spoilers extension

LANDING GEAR.question: 57: The brake & Accumulator pressure gauge shows pressure from:

options.text: A: The Yellow hydraulic system
B: The Accumulator only
C: The Green hydraulic system
D: Both Yellow brake system and the Brake Accumulator

LANDING GEAR.question: 58: The Hot light on the brake fan pushbutton illuminates when brake temperature reaches:

options.text: A: 250 deg C
B: 300 deg C
C: 350 deg C
D: 400 deg C

LANDING GEAR.question: 59: Max braking has been selected. Takeoff being aborted, engines in reverse, you have forgotten to arm the ground spoilers. Is autobrake activated?

options.text: A: No because spoilers will not deploy if not armed
B: Yes, provided speed is less than 72 knots
C: Yes, but only if Yellow hydraulic pressure is available
D: Yes, because spoilers will still deploy

LANDING GEAR.question: 60: On wheel page of ECAM, Autobrake is flashing green. What does it mean?

options.text: A: Autobrake is disengaged
B: Autobrake failure
C: Anti-skid failure
D: Autobrake in operation

LANDING GEAR.question: 61: On the ramp with APU running, park brake is set on, message on ECAM memo shows Park Brake.

options.text: A: In Green
B: In Yellow
C: In White
D: In White or Yellow

LANDING GEAR.question: 62: The landing gear indicator panel receives the information from micro switches and proximity detectors connected to:

options.text: A: BSCU
B: LGCIU 2
C: LGCIU 1
D: BSCU and LGCIU 2

LANDING GEAR.question: 63: The red arrow, near the landing gear lever illuminates when:

options.text: A: Landing gear is not up locked after retraction
B: Landing gear is in abnormal position
C: Landing gear is in transit
D: Landing gear is not down locked in approach configuration

LANDING GEAR.question: 64: Landing gear indicator panel UNLK light illuminates red if

options.text: A: Gear is extended by gravity and doors are not closed
B: Gear is extended normally and doors are not closed
C: Gear is not locked in selected position
D: Gear is not selected down by 1,000 ft RA.

LANDING GEAR.question: 65: The maximum speed with landing gear extended (VLE) is:
66: Which ADIRS close the safety valve of the green hydraulic supply when speed is > 260 kts.

options.text: A: ADIRS 1 & 2
B: ADIRS 1 & 3
C: ADIRS 2 & 3
D: ADDIRS 2 or 3

LANDING GEAR.question: 67: What is the maximum tyre speed?

options.text: A: 185 kts
B: 195 kts
C: 205 kts
D: 225 kts

DOORS.question: 1: How is it determined that the cockpit sliding window is closed and locked?

options.text: A: The pin is engaged.
B: The red ring below the release button should not be in view.
C: The locking pin was placed in the forward position when the window was closed.
D: The red ring below the release button should be in view.

DOORS.question: 2: Opening a passenger door from the outside disarms the door and the escape slide.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

DOORS.question: 3: What does illumination of the red cabin pressure light represent on the main cabin door?

options.text: A: This indicates that the evacuation slide is armed.
B: This indicates that the aircraft cabin is still pressurized and the cabin door should not be opened.
C: Both are correct

DOORS.question: 4: The cargo doors are powered by:

options.text: A: The blue electric pump.
B: The yellow hydraulic system before engine start and the green hydraulic system after engine start.
C: The yellow hydraulic system.
D: The blue hydraulic system before engine start and the green hydraulic system after engine start.

DOORS.question: 5: The forward and aft cargo doors can be opened from:

options.text: A: The inside and the outside.
B: The outside only

DOORS.question: 6: On the ECAM DOOR/OXY page, the SLIDE indication appears _____ when the slide is not disarmed.

options.text: A: White.
B: Amber.
C: Green.
D: Red.

DOORS.question: 7: Each passenger door has one CABIN PRESSURE warning light that:

options.text: A: Warns of residual pressure in the cabin.
B: Shows a possible unlocked door
C: Both are correct.

DOORS.question: 8: Where does the Door and Slide Control System (DSCS) generate warnings?

options.text: A: On ECAM.
B: On the doors.
C: Both are correct.

DOORS.question: 9: What happens to the cockpit door with electrical power failure?

options.text: A: It operates normally on HOT BAT bus.
B: It automatically unlocks.
C: It automatically locks from outside but stays unlock from inside.

DOORS.question: 10: The cockpit windows can be opened both from inside and outside.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

DOORS.question: 11: What does illumination of the white slide armed light represent on the main cabin door?

options.text: A: This indicates that the slide has properly inflated and is safe for use.
B: This indicates that the slide is armed and the slide will inflate if the door is opened from inside the aircraft.
C: This indicates that the main cabin door has not been properly closed.
D: This indicates that the main cabin door has not been properly closed but the slide is properly armed.

DOORS.question: 12: Can the flight compartment sliding windows be used as emergency exits?

options.text: A: Yes, in the cockpit coat closet is a rope ladder that can be used in such an event.
B: Yes, there are escape ropes mounted above each window behind an access panel.
C: No. They are not approved emergency exits.
D: No, they are too small.

DOORS.question: 13: When the electric pump is operating the FWD or AFT cargo doors, the only other yellow system devices that can operate are braking and engine 2 reverse.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

DOORS.question: 14: When the slide arming lever, on the emergency opening system, is in the ARMED position, where is the slide connected?

options.text: A: To the brackets on the underside of the fuselage.
B: To the brackets above the door.
C: To the floor brackets on both sides of the door.
D: All of the above

DOORS.question: 15: When the Cargo door switch for the yellow hydraulic pump is in use, the flight controls are:

options.text: A: Fully operational
B: Inhibited
C: Hydraulically locked by pressure from the electric pump
D: Only operated by the green system.

DOORS.question: 16: When opened in an emergency, the passenger entry doors:

options.text: A: Pneumatically assisted into the open position
B: Will need two cabin crew to push them open
C: Are assisted to the open position by slide inflation
D: Are electrically assisted into the open position.

DOORS.question: 17: If door handle is lifted and the white indicator illuminates, what does this mean?

options.text: A: The escape slide is armed and if you go on lifting the handle, door opens and slide will deploy.
B: Pneumatic assistance of the door has failed
C: The escape slide is in disarmed configuration
D: The cabin is still pressurized

ELECTRICAL.question: 1: The engine generators and APU generator are rated at _____ KVA.
2: The number 1 AC bus channel normally supplies power to _____ and to the _____ bus which supplies power to the ______ bus.

options.text: A: TR2 / AC ESS SHED / DC ESS SHED
B: TR1 / AC ESS SHED / DC ESS
C: TR1 / AC ESS / AC ESS SHED
D: TR1 / AC ESS / DC ESS SHED

ELECTRICAL.question: 3: The normal priority for supplying electrical power to the AC busses is:

options.text: A: External power, engine generators then APU
B: External power, APU, then engine generators
C: APU, external power then engine generators
D: Engine generators, external power then APU

ELECTRICAL.question: 4: The BATTERY BUS is normally powered by:

options.text: A: DC BUS 2
B: DC BUS 1 and DC BUS 2
C: DC bus 1 through a DC tie control relay.
D: DC bus 2 through a DC tie control relay.

ELECTRICAL.question: 5: The A-320 has _______ batteries in its main electrical system.
6: When no other power is available in flight, the static inverter converts _____ power to AC power for the ______ bus; and ______ powers the _______ bus.

options.text: A: BAT1 DC / AC ESS bus / BAT2 / DC ESS
B: BAT1 DC / AC ESS SHED / BAT2 / DC ESS SHED
C: BAT1 DC / AC ESS bus / BAT2 / DC ESS SHED
D: BAT1 DC / AC ESS bus / DC ESS

ELECTRICAL.question: 7: An AC ESS FEED switch located on the overhead panel shifts the power source for the AC ESS bus from:

options.text: A: AC bus1 to AC bus 2
B: AC bus 1 to AC Grnd/Flt bus
C: AC bus 2 to AC bus 1

ELECTRICAL.question: 8: Which of the following AC busses can be powered by the emergency generator?

options.text: A: AC bus 1
B: AC bus 2
C: AC ESS bus / AC ESS SHED bus

ELECTRICAL.question: 9: The RAT is connected directly (mechanically) to the Emergency Generator

options.text: A: True
B: False

ELECTRICAL.question: 10: After landing, in the emergency electrical configuration: the batteries automatically connect to the DC BAT bus when speed decreases below _______ knots.
11: The BAT FAULT light will illuminate when:

options.text: A: Battery voltage is low
B: Charging current increases at an abnormal rate
C: Charging current decreases at an abnormal rate.

ELECTRICAL.question: 12: Do not depress the IDG DISCONNECT switch for more than _______ to prevent damage to the disconnect mechanism.

options.text: A: 3 seconds
B: 7 seconds
C: 10 seconds
D: 15 seconds

ELECTRICAL.question: 13: The IDG Fault light indicates:

options.text: A: An IDG oil overheat
B: IDG low oil pressure.
C: IDG low oil pressure or IDG oil overheat
D: IDG has been disconnected

ELECTRICAL.question: 14: If normal electrical power is lost; essential cockpit lighting is maintained for the:

options.text: A: Captain’s instrument panel.
B: Standby compass
C: Right dome light (provided the dome selector is not off).
D: All of the above.

ELECTRICAL.question: 15: You enter a dark cockpit, what action is necessary before checking the battery voltages?

options.text: A: You have to check that the external power is on.
B: You have to ensure that at least one battery is on.
C: You have to ensure that both batteries are on.
D: You have to verify that both batteries are off.

ELECTRICAL.question: 16: Having started the APU, how can you get the APU generator to power the electrical system?

options.text: A: The APU generator must be switch on.
B: By pushing the EXT PWR pushbutton thus disconnecting the external power.
C: By pushing the BUS TIE pushbutton.
D: You are unable to as the APU power output is outside normal parameters.

ELECTRICAL.question: 17: Are there any limitations associated with disconnecting an IDG?

options.text: A: Never disconnect an IDG in flight, or push the IDG disconnect push button for more than 30 seconds.
B: There is no limitation
C: Never disconnect an IDG in flight, or push the IDG disconnect push button for more than 5 seconds.
D: Never disconnect an IDG unless the engine is running, nor push the IDG disconnect push button for more than 3 seconds.

ELECTRICAL.question: 18: Which voltage requires recharging or replacing the batteries?

options.text: A: 20 volts or less.
B: 24 volts or less.
C: 25 volts or less.
D: 26 volts or less.

ELECTRICAL.question: 19: The APU is supplying the electrical system. What is the order of priority for the different generators?

options.text: A: Engines, external power, APU.
B: APU, engines, external power.
C: External power, engines, APU.
D: APU, external power, engines.

ELECTRICAL.question: 20: What is the significance of the green collared circuit breakers?

options.text: A: Green collared circuit breakers are pulled when flying on battery power only.
B: Green collared circuit breakers are monitored by the ECAM.
C: Green collared circuit breakers are not to be reset.
D: Green collared circuit breakers are AC powered.

ELECTRICAL.question: 21: If batteries are the only source of power in flight, how long will battery power be available?

options.text: A: Between 22 and 30 minutes depending on equipment in use.
B: Until the APU is started.
C: Two hours and 30 minutes dependent on equipment in use.
D: 45 minutes dependent on equipment in use.

ELECTRICAL.question: 22: What is the minimum voltage when conducting a BATTERY CHECK?

options.text: A: 28 volts.
B: Less than 60 amps in 10 seconds.
C: Greater than 24 volts.
D: Greater than 25 volts.

ELECTRICAL.question: 23: A battery fault light will illuminate when:

options.text: A: The batteries have auto disconnected due to low voltage.
B: Battery voltage drops below a predetermined level.
C: Battery charging current increases at an abnormal rate.

ELECTRICAL.question: 24: Which flight control computer will be inoperative with gear extension while in the Emergency Electrical Configuration?

options.text: A: FAC 1 and ELAC 1.
B: SEC 1
C: SEC 1 and ELAC 1
D: FAC 1

ELECTRICAL.question: 25: If the battery voltages are below the minimum, how do you charge them?

options.text: A: You have to call a mechanic because the batteries can only be charged by maintenance.
B: I have to check that the BAT pushbuttons are on and switch the external power on.
C: I have to switch the external power to ON and switch the batteries off.
D: I have to start the APU as the batteries can only be charged by the APU generator.

ELECTRICAL.question: 26: What is the function of APU GEN push button located on the overhead electrical panel?

options.text: A: Push this button to automatically start the APU.
B: When selected to OFF the APU generator field is de-energized.
C: Both are correct.

ELECTRICAL.question: 27: Is it possible to parallel generators?

options.text: A: Of course yes.
B: Only with the RAT deployed.
C: The electrical system will not allow “paralleling” of generators.
D: Only one engine generator may be paralleled with the APU.

ELECTRICAL.question: 28: While operating on Emergency Electrical Power with the landing gear lowered which of the following control laws is in effect?

options.text: A: Backup.
B: Direct.
C: Alternate.
D: Backup or alternate

ELECTRICAL.question: 29: What cockpit lighting is available during an emergency electrical situation?

options.text: A: Emergency path lighting only.
B: Right side Dome light, main panel flood lights (left two columns only), and the standby compass light.
C: Located on normal circuit breaker panels.
D: Right side dome light, main panel flood lights, and the standby compass light.

ELECTRICAL.question: 30: What is the function of the GEN 1 LINE push button?

options.text: A: When selected OFF the avionics compartment isolation valves close.
B: When selected OFF the #1 generator powers all AC busses.
C: When selected OFF generator # 1 is removed from all busses but continues to power one fuel pump in each wing.

ELECTRICAL.question: 31: During a routine flight, which of the following would result after the loss of Gen #2 and the subsequent start of the APU?

options.text: A: The APU would now power both sides of the electrical system.
B: All systems return to normal and the RAT must be restowed.
C: Eng gen #1 continues to power AC bus #1 and downstream systems. The APU powers AC bus #2 and downstream systems.

ELECTRICAL.question: 32: When does the RAT automatically deploy?

options.text: A: With the loss of two hydraulic systems.
B: Electrical power to both AC BUS #1 & #2 is lost and the aircraft speed is above 100 knots.
C: Both are correct.

ELECTRICAL.question: 33: During the five seconds it takes for the RAT to extend:

options.text: A: The BATTERIES power both BATT HOT busses, ESS DC SHED, and ESS AC SHED through the STATIC INVERTER.
B: The BATTERIES power both BATT HOT busses, ESS DC, and ESS AC through the STATIC INVERTER.
C: The STATIC INVERTER powers both BATT HOT busses, ESS DC, and ESS AC through the ESS AC SHED busses.
D: The BATTERIES power both BATT HOT busses.

ELECTRICAL.question: 34: The purpose of the AUTO BUS TIE is to allow either engine-driven IDG to automatically power both main AC buses in the event of a generator loss until either ground power or the APU generator is activated.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

ELECTRICAL.question: 35: When will the RAT & EMER GEN red FAULT light illuminate?

options.text: A: When the EMER GEN is not supplying electrical power, AC busses #1 & #2 are unpowered and the nose gear is up.
B: When the RAT is deployed using hydraulic RAT MAN ON push button.
C: Both are correct.

ELECTRICAL.question: 36: What is the significance of the circuit breakers on the overhead panel?

options.text: A: They are not monitored by ECAM.
B: Cannot be reset.
C: They may be operational in the Emergency Electrical Configuration.
D: They are mainly AC powered.

ELECTRICAL.question: 37: If both engine generators are powering the system, and one subsequently fails, are any busses unpowered?

options.text: A: Only the AC ESS shed bus.
B: No, but some loads are shed in both main galleys.
C: Yes, those associated with the failed generator.

ELECTRICAL.question: 38: How many times can you reset a circuit breaker?

options.text: A: Once.
B: Once, if authorized by the procedures.
C: Twice.
D: Twice, if authorized by the procedures.

ELECTRICAL.question: 39: On the cockpit overhead panel, there is a three position EMERGENCY EXIT Light switch. What lights are associated with this switch?

options.text: A: Exit signs, emergency lights, and escape path lighting.
B: Exit signs, emergency lights, main panel flood lights, and escape path lighting.
C: Exit signs, emergency lights, dome lights, main panel flood lights, and the standby compass light.

ELECTRICAL.question: 40: Which flight control computers are operational in the Emergency Electrical Power configuration (gear down and batteries powering the system)?

options.text: A: All are operational.
B: ELAC 1, SEC 1, and FAC 1.
C: ELAC 1 and 2, SEC 1 and 2, FAC 1.
D: ELAC 1 and SEC 1.

ELECTRICAL.question: 41: The emergency generator supplies power as long as:

options.text: A: The landing gear is down.
B: The RAT is deployed
C: The RAT is deployed and the landing gear is down
D: The landing gear is up

ELECTRICAL.question: 42: Which radios are inoperative with gear extension while in the emergency electrical configuration?

options.text: A: DME 1 and transponder 1
B: DME 1, DDRMI, and transponder 1.
C: DME, and transponder 1.
D: ILS 2, DME, and ADF.

ELECTRICAL.question: 43: While operating on Emergency Electrical Power with the landing gear lowered which of the following statements is correct?

options.text: A: If the APU is not operating it should be started at this time.
B: The APU will not start until the aircraft has come to a complete stop and all power has been removed for 15 seconds.
C: On the ground at 100 knots, the DC BATTERY BUS automatically reconnects to the batteries allowing APU start.
D: At 70 knots ESS AC is disconnected from the batteries.

ELECTRICAL.question: 44: If during a normal flight the BUS TIE push button is depressed to “OFF”, what effect would this have on power to the busses?

options.text: A: None.
B: All power would be lost and the aircraft would be powered by the batteries until the RAT was up to speed.
C: The power transfer would switch to the opposite bus.
D: This is not possible as the bus tie contactors are locked out during flight.

ELECTRICAL.question: 45: While operating on Emergency Electrical Power (EMER GEN powering the system, FAC #1 reset) which of the following control laws are in effect?

options.text: A: Manual
B: Alternate.
C: Backup
D: Manual and backup

ELECTRICAL.question: 46: Can you reconnect an IDG in flight?

options.text: A: Yes, but only after contacting maintenance control.
B: Yes, push and hold the IDG pb until the GEN fault light is no longer illuminated.
C: No, it is not possible.

ELECTRICAL.question: 47: Which communication and navigation radios are operational in the Emergency Electrical Configuration with the EMER GEN powering the system?

options.text: A: ACP 1 and 2, VHF 1, HF, RMP 1, VOR 1, and ILS 1.
B: VHF 1, RMP 1, VOR 1.
C: RMP #1 & #2, VHF #1, HF (if equipped), ACP #1, VOR #1 and ILS #1.
D: All radios are lost.

ELECTRICAL.question: 48: What is the meaning of the green AVAIL light?

options.text: A: External power is plugged in and parameters are normal. You must push the external power to connect it
B: External power is available to the batteries only.
C: The external power panel door has been opened
D: External power is supplying the aircraft systems

ELECTRICAL.question: 50: What does the blue EXT PWR ON light mean?

options.text: A: External power is plugged in and parameters are normal
B: External power is supplying the aircraft’s electrical system.
C: There is a fault with the external power.

ELECTRICAL.question: 51: If EXTERNAL power is available and within limits:

options.text: A: It will automatically close the bus tie contactors when connected by the ground crew.
B: The green AVAIL light will illuminate on the EXT PWR push button.
C: The BUS TIE push button illuminates.

ELECTRICAL.question: 52: Is it possible to determine the source of power for aircraft busses

options.text: A: It is indicated on the electrical schematic overhead.
B: No it is not possible.
C: Yes, press the ECAM ELEC push button and view the electrical schematic on the ECAM
D: Only when operating in the Emergency Electrical Configuration.

ELECTRICAL.question: 53: Both batteries are charged by the external power unit. Approximately how long does the charging process take?

options.text: A: 10 minutes.
B: 20 minutes.
C: 30 minutes.
D: Between 30 and 45 minutes.

ELECTRICAL.question: 54: The GALLEY FAULT light illuminates when any generator is exceeding 80% of its rated output.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

ELECTRICAL.question: 55: While operating on Emergency Electrical Power (EMER GEN powering the system) what should the crew accomplish prior to lowering the landing gear?

options.text: A: Check to see that the FMGC has auto tuned the appropriate NAV facility for the approach to be accomplished.
B: Depress the guarded RMP NAV push button and tune the appropriate NAV facility and course for the approach to be accomplished
C: Both are correct.

ELECTRICAL.question: 56: What would cause the GALLEY fault light to illuminate?

options.text: A: The flight attendants have all the coffee makers and ovens on at once.
B: The Main Galley has shed.
C: The load on any generator is above 100% of its rated output.
D: The Aft Galley has shed.

ELECTRICAL.question: 57: While operating on Emergency Electrical Power (EMER GEN powering the system) how is it possible to properly complete the ECAM checklist with only an upper display?

options.text: A: Depress and hold the specific ECAM page push button on the ECAM control panel.
B: Transfer occurs automatically.
C: This is not possible. Use the cockpit operating manual.

ELECTRICAL.question: 58: After IDG disconnection why do you get a GALLEY SHED indication on the SD?

options.text: A: It is a reminder to push the GALLEY pushbutton to manually shed the main galley.
B: It is a reminder to get the flight attendants to switch off galley equipment to decrease the load on the remaining generator.
C: It is a reminder that the main galley has been shed automatically following the loss of one generator.

ELECTRICAL.question: 59: Which busses will be powered after the RAT is extended and the EMER GEN begins producing power?

options.text: A: BATT HOT busses, ESS DC, ESS DC SHED, ESS AC and ESS AC SHED.
B: The STATIC INVERTER would power both HOT BATT busses, ESS DC and ESS AC through the ESS AC SHED busses.
C: The BATTERIES would power both HOT BATT busses, ESS DC and ESS AC through the STATIC INVERTER.
D: ESS DC, ESS DC SHED, ESS AC and ESS AC SHED.

ELECTRICAL.question: 60: Engine #1 has just been started and the APU is inoperative. The EXT PWR push button blue ON light is illuminated. Which of the statements below is correct?

options.text: A: External power is supplying all electrical needs.
B: Engine Gen #1 is supplying AC bus #1 and the downstream systems, and AC bus #2 through the bus tie contactors.
C: Gen #1 supplies AC bus #1 and (generally) the downstream systems; Ext power supplies AC bus #2.

ELECTRICAL.question: 61: In cruise, you have suddenly a Master Warning and caution comes on with ELEC EMER CONFIG and APP OFF. You notice a red FAULT light on the RAT & EMER GEN pushbutton. What do you think of this indication?

options.text: A: The EMER GEN is not yet supplying the system.
B: The RAT has failed. You will have to turn the batteries to OFF.
C: The FAULT light is always on when are in ELEC EMER CONFIG.
D: The RAT has failed, you have to try to reconnect both IDG’s.

ELECTRICAL.question: 62: When are the Essential Shed buses powered by the battery?

options.text: A: Never. The purpose of the shed buses is to reduce the load on the batteries.
B: In case of double generator failure.
C: After every IDG connection

ELECTRICAL.question: 63: The AC Essential bus is powered by the battery at speed above 50 kt.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

ELECTRICAL.question: 64: In normal electrical configuration, how is DC ESS bus supplied:

options.text: A: From TR 1 via DC Bus 1 and DC Bat Bus
B: From ESS TR
C: From TR 2
D: From Bat 2

ELECTRICAL.question: 65: What happens in case of total loss of main generators?

options.text: A: The RAT is automatically extended and powers the yellow system which drives the emergency generator
B: The RAT is automatically extended and powers the blue system which drives the emergency generator
C: The RAT has to be manually extended
D: The RAT is extended and mechanically connected to the emergency generator.

ELECTRICAL.question: 66: DC Bat Bus can be supplied by:

options.text: A: DC Bus 1 or batteries
B: DC Bus 1, DC Bus 2 or batteries
C: DC Bus 2 or batteries
D: DC Bus 1 only

ELECTRICAL.question: 67: Normal minimum battery voltage before APU start is:

options.text: A: No minimum
B: 27.5 Volts
C: 25.5 Volts
D: 22.5 Volts

ELECTRICAL.question: 68: When disconnecting the IDG the button should be pressed:

options.text: A: For no more than 5 seconds
B: Until the fault light goes out
C: For longer than 3 seconds
D: For no more than 3 seconds

ELECTRICAL.question: 69: Where can the battery voltage be checked?

options.text: A: On the ECAM elec. Page only
B: On the elec. overhead panel and ECAM E/WD
C: On the elec. overhead panel only
D: On the elec. overhead panel and ECAM elec. Page

ELECTRICAL.question: 70: In flight on batteries only, the AC ESS Shed bus and DC ESS Shed bus are lost.

options.text: A: Yes
B: No
C: Only A/C ESS Shed Bus is lost
D: Only D/C ESS Shed Bus is lost

ELECTRICAL.question: 71: The static inverter works:

options.text: A: Always
B: When aircraft speed is > 50 kt and on batteries only *
C: When one main generator fails
D: Only when generator 2 fails

ELECTRICAL.question: 72: If a TR fails:

options.text: A: The other TR automatically replaces the faulty one and the ESS TR supplies the DC Ess Bus
B: The static inverter replaces the faulty TR
C: The DC Bus on the faulty side is lost
D: The Emergency generator supplies DC power on the faulty side.

ELECTRICAL.question: 73: In flight in case of loss of all main generators, emergency generator not running, the DC ESS Bus is supplied by:

options.text: A: Hot bus 2
B: ESS TR
C: Hot Bus and ESS TR
D: Hot Bus 1

ELECTRICAL.question: 74: If AC Bus 1 fails the AC ESS bus is supplied by:

options.text: A: Emer Gen.
B: The RAT
C: Static Inverter
D: AC Bus 2

ENGINES.question: 1: The Full Authority Digital Engine Control (FADEC) controls which of the following functions:

options.text: A: Fuel metering
B: Engine limits
C: Automatic and manual starting.
D: All of the above.

ENGINES.question: 2: The FADEC is normally powered by:

options.text: A: The RAT
B: Its own magnetic alternator
C: The normal aircraft electrical system

ENGINES.question: 3: During an automatic start sequence; selecting the ENG MASTER switch to on:

options.text: A: Closes the pack valves.
B: Initiates the start sequence.
C: Displays the ECAM engine page
D: First two statements are correct

ENGINES.question: 4: The FADEC has control during a manual engine start sequence except for:

options.text: A: The high pressure fuel valve.
B: The start valve.
C: An automatic abort.

ENGINES.question: 5: The A/THR is armed on the ground provided at least one FD is on by:

options.text: A: Setting the throttles to TO/GA.
B: Automatically at engine start.
C: With engines running; pressing the A/THR p/b manually.

ENGINES.question: 6: Continuous ignition is automatically provided during the following:

options.text: A: Flex or TO/GA thrust is selected on the ground.
B: ENG ANTI ICE switch is ON
C: Engine surge on stall occurs in flight.
D: Any of the above

ENGINES.question: 7: If a throttle is set between two detents; the FADEC selects the rating limit:

options.text: A: Determined by the throttle position.
B: Corresponding to the higher mode.
C: Corresponding to the lower mode.

ENGINES.question: 8: When the A/THR system is in use:

options.text: A: The throttles move automatically according to FADEC commands.
B: The throttles can only be moved manually.
C: The throttles will move when the A/THR p/b is used.

ENGINES.question: 9: A/THR engagement is confirmed when “A/THR” is displayed in ______ in the right column of the FMA.

options.text: A: Green
B: Blue
C: White

ENGINES.question: 10: If an A/THR disconnect switch is pushed and held for more than _______ seconds; the A/THR system is disconnected for the remainder of the flight; including the _______.

options.text: A: 10 Seconds - Alpha floor Protection
B: 12 Seconds - Alpha floor Protection
C: 15 Seconds - Alpha floor Protection
D: 18 Seconds - Alpha floor Protection

ENGINES.question: 11: Takeoff can be performed using which power settings?

options.text: A: Any manual setting.
B: FLEX and MCT.
C: CLIMB and TO/GA
D: FLEX/MCT and TO/GA.

ENGINES.question: 12: When is T.O. INHIBIT and LDG INHIBIT active?

options.text: A: TO 750 feet AGL, LND below 1500 feet AGL.
B: TO 1000 feet AGL, LND below 1000 feet AGL.
C: TO 1500 feet AGL, LND below 750 feet AGL.
D: TO 1500 feet AGL, LND below 1000 feet AGL.

ENGINES.question: 13: How many thrust lever positions are there, and how are they labeled?

options.text: A: There are 6 thrust levers positions: TO/GA, MCT, FLEX, CL, IDLE and REV IDLE.
B: There are 6 thrust levers positions: TO/GA, FLX/MCT, CL, IDLE, REV IDLE and MREV.
C: There are 4 thrust levers positions: TO/GA, FLX/MCT, CL, IDLE.
D: There are 5 thrust levers positions: TO/GA, FLX/MCT, CL, IDLE and REV IDLE.

ENGINES.question: 14: You are just about to take off. You have not inserted a FLEX temperature. Can you still takeoff?

options.text: A: Yes, by setting the thrust levers to the CLIMB detent.
B: Yes, by setting the thrust levers to the FLEX/MCT detent.
C: Yes, but only using the TO/GA detent.
D: Not until a FLEX temperature is inserted.

ENGINES.question: 15: During an engine start sequence, the gray background on N2 disappears at about 57%. What does this indicate?

options.text: A: That the igniters are no longer being powered.
B: That the start sequence has finished and all engine parameters have stabilized.
C: That the start valve air pressure has dropped.
D: That there is a start fault and a dry crank is in progress.

ENGINES.question: 16: What does the FLEX represent in the FLX/MCT detent?

options.text: A: This is a reduced thrust setting used for takeoff.
B: This is the maximum continuous thrust setting for single-engine operations.
C: This is the thrust setting that should be chosen in the case of a single-engine go-around.
D: This is a derated thrust according the ground temperature of the day.

ENGINES.question: 17: How many FADEC’s are installed in the aircraft?

options.text: A: Two, one per engine.
B: One, with two Engine Control Units (ECU).
C: Two per engine.
D: Two, one is the active FADEC and the other is a standby.

ENGINES.question: 18: What is required for the FADEC to compute a reduced thrust setting?

options.text: A: A FLEX temperature must be entered on the INIT page of the MCDU.
B: Nothing, it is an automatic function of the FADEC.
C: A FLEX temperature must be entered on the TAKE OFF PERF page of the MCDU.

ENGINES.question: 19: Using manual thrust, the thrust lever position will determine the thrust setting for the engine.

options.text: A: True. They will operate like conventional throttles.
B: True, but care must be taken not to overspeed the engines.
C: False, the next higher detent will be the thrust limit.

ENGINES.question: 20: What is considered to be the active range of the A/THR system?

options.text: A: During single engine operations from just above the IDLE stop to the FLX/MCT detent.
B: During two engine operations from just above the IDLE stop to the CL detent.
C: Both are correct.

ENGINES.question: 21: If the thrust levers are set in the idle detent, is Alpha floor protection still available?

options.text: A: Yes Thrust lever position is disregarded.
B: Yes, as long as “A/THR” appears in Column five.
C: No, because the IDLE detent is out of the A/THR active range.

ENGINES.question: 22: Is there any mechanical linkage between the thrust levers and the engines?

options.text: A: There is a fiber optic backup.
B: There is a mechanical linkage in case the ECU fails.
C: No, it is electrically powered and hydraulically actuated.
D: No, it is totally electrical.

ENGINES.question: 23: What is Alpha floor protection?

options.text: A: It helps prevent the aircraft from stalling and protects against windshear encounters during takeoff and approach.
B: It is a function of the flight control laws to prevent the aircraft from stalling.
C: It helps prevent the aircraft from stalling by limiting the angle of bank at low airspeeds.
D: It helps prevent the aircraft from stalling by limiting the angle of climb at high airspeeds.

ENGINES.question: 24: Alpha floor protection is available:

options.text: A: From lift off and down to 100 feet radio altitude in the landing configuration.
B: From lift off and down to 50 feet radio altitude in the landing configuration.
C: From lift off and down to 500 feet radio altitude in the landing configuration.
D: From lift off and down to 750 feet radio altitude in the landing configuration.

ENGINES.question: 25: How do you arm the A/THR in flight?

options.text: A: A/THR switch ON when throttles are in the engagement mode.
B: A/THR switch ON when throttles are not in the engagement mode.

ENGINES.question: 26: What is the difference between variable thrust and the speed mode?

options.text: A: In the fixed thrust mode, thrust is fixed and the elevator controls the speed.
B: In the variable thrust mode, thrust is fixed and speed is controlled by the elevator.
C: In the fixed thrust mode, thrust is variable and speed is controlled by the elevator.

ENGINES.question: 27: The left column, first line of the FMA is used to indicate:

options.text: A: If A/THR is off, armed, or active.
B: The mode of the A/THR in use when A/THR is armed or active.
C: Amber caution messages.
D: The thrust indication.

ENGINES.question: 28: What are the two basic modes of the A/THR system?

options.text: A: Thrust and Mach.
B: Thrust and speed
C: Variable thrust and fixed speed
D: Mach and speed.

ENGINES.question: 29: Can the engines be overboosted in the TOGA position?

options.text: A: Yes, if the autothrust function is not active.
B: No, because the ECU provides engine protection limit by monitoring N1, N2, and HMU fuel flow adjustments.
C: No, because the EIU is responsible for monitoring N1 and N2.

ENGINES.question: 30: During a manual start, how is the start valve opened?

options.text: A: It is automatic once the ENG MASTER is placed to the ON position.
B: By depressing the ENG MAN START pushbutton’s on the overhead panel.
C: By depressing the ENG MAN START pushbutton’s on the overhead panel while the ENG MODE selector is out of the NORM position.

ENGINES.question: 31: Is any thrust lever action required if an engine failed at rotation while using FLEX takeoff power?

options.text: A: Yes.
B: No.

ENGINES.question: 32: When does oil quantity indication begin to pulse?

options.text: A: Decreasing below 5 qts.
B: During engine start.
C: Oil quantity detector or pressure fault.

ENGINES.question: 33: Does the FADEC provide EGT limit protection constantly?

options.text: A: Yes, in all phases of flight.
B: No, EGT limit protection is only available during ground auto starts.
C: No, EGT limit protection is only available during ground auto starts and single-engine operations.

ENGINES.question: 34: Auto Thrust System: When are the throttles in the engagement range?

options.text: A: Both throttles are above idle but not above the CLB detent when both engines are running.
B: A single throttle of an operating engine is above idle but not above the MCT detent when one engine is running.
C: All of the above.

ENGINES.question: 35: The idle setting on the aircraft is capable of modulating due to certain conditions. During descent, what might

options.text: cause the IDLE N1 setting to increase?
A: The slats are extended.
B: For a higher than normal bleed air demand or warmer than normal engine oil temp in flight.
C: Both are correct.

ENGINES.question: 36: Verification that Autothrust (A/THR) is active can be made by:

options.text: A: Watching the automatic movement of the thrust levers.
B: Only when the thrust levers are set at TOGA.
C: Only by looking at column five of the FMA.

ENGINES.question: 37: When Alpha floor is activated, what power setting is automatically commanded and what FMA annunciation would appear in Column one?

options.text: A: TOGA / A. FLOOR
B: CLB / CLB
C: MCT / THR LK
D: THR / LK

ENGINES.question: 38: Holding the instinctive disconnect push button’s for more than fifteen seconds will:

options.text: A: Disengage the A/THR (including Alpha Floor) until below 1000 feet AGL for the remainder of the flight.
B: Disengage the A/THR (including Alpha Floor) until below 500 feet AGL for the remainder of the flight.
C: Disengage the A/THR (excluding Alpha Floor) for the remainder of the flight.
D: Disengage the A/THR (including Alpha Floor) for the remainder of the flight.

ENGINES.question: 39: During the automatic start sequence of ENG 2, you notice that only igniter B is powered. Is it normal?

options.text: A: Yes, igniter A is only used for engine anti-ice.
B: No, normally both igniters are used for all engine starts.
C: Yes, igniter B is always used for ENG 2 start.
D: Yes, igniters are used alternately for engine start.

ENGINES.question: 40: As far as FMA annunciations are concerned, what would indicate that the A/THR system is active?

options.text: A: SPEED appears in green in column one, line one.
B: A/THR changes from blue to white as shown in column five, line three.
C: A/THR changes from white to blue in column five, line one.
D: SPEED appears in amber in column one, line one.

ENGINES.question: 41: If a thrust lever is set between two detents, the FADEC selects the rating limit corresponding to the higher limit.

options.text: A: True. This limit is displayed on the upper ECAM.
B: False. For safety reasons, it always selects the rating limit corresponding to the lower limit.

ENGINES.question: 42: What would happen during the takeoff roll if the thrust levers were set to the FLX/MCT detent without FLEX temperature being entered?

options.text: A: Nothing, the thrust setting would be at FLEX since FADEC automatically calculates a reduced thrust setting.
B: The thrust setting would be MCT and there would be no corresponding warnings.
C: A LEVEL TWO warning would sound along with the appearance of an ECAM message.

ENGINES.question: 43: What abnormals would cause the FADEC to automatically abort a start?

options.text: A: A hot start, an overtemp, a stalled start or no lightoff.
B: An engine overspeed.
C: A hot start, a stalled start, an overtemp or APU underspeed.
D: A hot start, an overtemp or an engine overspeed.

ENGINES.question: 44: During an in-flight start or a manual start, will the FADEC auto abort for an abnormal?

options.text: A: Yes. It will for an in-flight start (but not for a manual start).
B: Yes.
C: No.

ENGINES.question: 45: For reverser actuation, the left engine uses ____ hydraulic system pressure and the right engine uses _____ hydraulic system pressure

options.text: A: Green - Yellow.
B: Yellow - Blue.
C: Yellow - Green.
D: Blue - Green.

ENGINES.question: 46: While flying the airplane with A/THR active, the speed knob is pulled and turned to a selected speed that happens to be slower than Alpha prot. What speed will the airplane slow to?

options.text: A: VLS.
B: Green Dot + 5 kts.
C: Green dot.
D: Green dot + 10 kts

ENGINES.question: 47: Where is the thrust reduction altitude found and is the number always the same?

options.text: A: Column four, row three of the FMA. It will always be 1500 ft. AGL.
B: TAKE OFF PERF page of the MCDU (it can be modified).
C: PROG page of the MCDU. It can be modified in order to meet constraints.
D: TAKE OFF PERF page of the MCDU. It cannot be modified.

ENGINES.question: 48: During a manual start, what function does the FADEC perform?

options.text: A: Passive monitoring of the start sequence, to close the start valve and cut off the ignition on the ground.
B: To control the start sequence and take corrective action in case of a failure or malfunction.
C: The FADEC does not perform any function during a manual start and all actions have to be carried out by the pilots.

ENGINES.question: 49: During normal operation, in what detent are the thrust levers positioned once the thrust reduction altitude has been reached?

options.text: A: CL
B: MCT
C: FLX
D: CRZ

ENGINES.question: 50: After takeoff the A/THR will not become active until:

options.text: A: The thrust levers are placed in the CLIMB position.
B: The thrust levers are moved out of the TO/GA or FLEX/MCT detents.
C: The autopilot is engaged.
D: The A/THR pushbutton is manually selected ON.

ENGINES.question: 51: Continuous ignition is provided automatically when:

options.text: A: ENG ANTI ICE is selected ON and/or engine flameout is detected in flight
B: ENG ANTI ICE is selected ON.
C: ENG ANTI ICE is selected ON and/or engine flameout is detected in flight and/or the EIU fails.

ENGINES.question: 52: Is it possible to disconnect Alpha floor?

options.text: A: No, Alpha floor protection is always available.
B: Yes, by placing the thrust levers to IDLE.
C: Yes, by depressing the autothrottle push button on the FCU.

ENGINES.question: 53: The FADEC will automatically abort an abnormal start thereby providing engine limit protection, but will the FADEC also automatically dry crank the engine?

options.text: A: No, that is why there is a CRANK selection on the ENG MODE selector.
B: Yes, even if the crew interrupts the start by placing the ENG MASTER switch to OFF.
C: Yes, as long as the ENG MASTER switch remains in the ON position.

ENGINES.question: 54: What would happen in flight if the FADEC’s alternator failed?

options.text: A: Automatic control of the engine would be lost.
B: The standby channel of the ECU would take over.
C: The FADEC would now be powered using ship’s power.
D: The FADEC would now be powered using ship’s battery power.

ENGINES.question: 55: You are in the middle of a manual engine start. What are you looking for when you select ENG MASTER 2 ON?

options.text: A: The fuel used is reset, fuel flow is indicated and IGNITION message on the E/WD.
B: The fuel flow is reset, an igniter is powered and fuel used is indicated.
C: The fuel used is reset, both igniters are powered and fuel flow is indicated.
D: The fuel used is reset, both igniters are powered and N2 is increasing.

ENGINES.question: 56: Each FADEC is a dual channel (A&B) computer providing full engine management.

options.text: A: True.
B: False.

ENGINES.question: 57: In addition to when the engine is operating, when else will the FADEC be powered?

options.text: A: When the FADEC GND PWR pb on the maintenance panel is depressed, or the ENG MASTER switch is placed to ON.
B: When the FADEC control switch is placed to the IGN/START position.

C: For five minutes after electrical power is applied to the aircraft, when the FADEC GND PWR pb on the maintenance panel is depressed, or when the ENG MODE control switch is placed to IGN/START position.
D: As long as electrical power is established on the aircraft, the FADEC is powered.

ENGINES.question: 58: During an automatic start, the FADEC controls:

options.text: A: The start valves, igniters and fuel flow.
B: The start valves, igniters, HP and LP fuel valves.
C: The igniters and fuel flow.
D: The start valves, igniters, HP and LP fuel valves, and fuel flow.

ENGINES.question: 59: How is manual arming of the A/THR system accomplished?

options.text: A: By pressing the A/THR pb on the FCU confirm the pushbutton illuminates green or confirm an A/THR annunciation is displayed in column 5 of the FMA
B: By placing the thrust levers into the active range.
C: Advance at least one thrust lever to the TOGA or FLX/MCT detent with at least one Flight Director (FD) on.

ENGINES.question: 60: You are at the start of a descent and a blue N1 arc is displayed showing the new thrust demand. When does this happen?

options.text: A: Whenever the thrust levers are moved out of the CLIMB position.
B: Whenever there is a power change in manual thrust.
C: Whenever there is a power change with the autopilot engaged.
D: Whenever there is power change with auto thrust engaged.

ENGINES.question: 61: A few seconds after selecting reverse, the amber REV indication changes to green. What does this mean?

options.text: A: The reversers have been re-stowed.
B: The reversers are now fully deployed.
C: The reverse thrust selection has been acknowledged
D: The reversers are unlocked.

ENGINES.question: 62: During engine start the amber FAULT light on the ENG MASTER panel illuminates. This indicates:

options.text: A: A failure in the automatic start sequence.
B: A failure of the ENG MODE SELECTOR.
C: A failure in the engine fire extinguishing system.

ENGINES.question: 63: Which steps of a manual start are being taken care of by the FADEC?

options.text: A: Starter valve closure and ignition cut off.
B: Starter valve opening and ignition start.
C: Starter valve closure and ignition start.
D: Starter valve opening and ignition cut off.

ENGINES.question: 64: Can Alpha-floor be disengaged while in Alpha Protection?

options.text: A: Yes, by manually disengaging the auto throttles.
B: No, the system is designed to avoid such a disengagement.
C: Yes, by reducing at idle one of the throttles (for more than 5 seconds)
